title: family dream holiday cuba green swimming pool poo stained toilets
story: Mother Gayle Evans said she broke down in tears as she witnessed the family’s first trip away together ruined.The troop were there to celebrate Gayle’s th birthday, and with children growing fast, she said it might be one of the last chances to get them all together.But what they found at the Brisas del Caribe hotel was a world away from the hotels glossy brochure images.She told the Birmingham Mail: We spent weeks dreaming about it, of lying on the gorgeous beach and paddling in the sea, splashing in the pools, sipping cocktails in the piano bar - we thought it was going to be wonderful.“I just burst into tears. It was awful. I could not believe how bad it was.The trip included Gayle, husband Steve, daughters Ayla, , and Gabby, , and son Jaz,  and his girlfriend Laura, .Gayle described the hotel as being “in a state of decay”, complete with exposed electronics and obviously used towels in the rooms.There was litter everywhere, the pools had green scum on the surface and there was broken furniture and beach beds.To add insult to injury, nearly the whole family were laid out with a stomach bug during the trip.The family submitted a catalogue of complaints to their tour rep on the first day of their stay and asked for a move to another hotel - but were advised there was nowhere that was better quality than the one they were in.The holiday company the family had booked through, The Holiday Place, responded to the complaints to offer a meagre £ voucher each off any future break with the company.The Holiday Place told the Birmingham Mail: Due to GDPRwe cannot discuss this case with you however and we have been in contact with the client to handle the matter directly.The hotel has an average rating of .  on TripAdvisor.The Sun Online have contacted the hotel for comment.Despite the poor accommodation, Gayle said the family enjoyed the surrounding stunning beaches of Varader.

title: nicknames pregnancy bump craving britain
story: A poll of , mums and dads revealed nine in  used an alternative name for their baby while pregnant, with ‘Button’, ‘Sprout’ and ‘Pebble’ also popular monikers.Overall the nation’s favourite bump nickname is ‘Bean’, used by one in  expectant couples.‘Jellybean, ‘Sprog’ or ‘Spoglett’ and ‘Little Man or Little Miss’ also feature in the top , as well as ‘Prawn’, ‘Monster’ and ‘Bambino’.But for  per cent, the bump’s nickname stuck and they continued to use it well after the birth.And for one in  parents, it even ended up influencing the final name given to the child.The study was conducted by ChannelMum, whose founder Siobhan Freegard said: “Choosing a bump nickname is a modern rite of passage where the child really starts to feel like an inidual person.Becoming a parent starts long before your baby is born and naming the bump is the first step to bonding with your tot.“But with Bean revealed at the nation’s number one bump name, it’s interesting to see how many of the other top nicknames relate to food – maybe mums’ cravings are helping couples choose ”The study revealed that parents undergoing IVF chose Elsa, Olaf and Snowflake as the most common names given to frozen embryos – after the hit Disney film Frozen.And for almost three in  prospective parents, their choice of nickname was inspired by the blurry image of an ultrasound scan.Others started referring to their bump using a term related to where the baby was conceived, it’s due date or descriptions of what their baby looks like in pregnancy books or apps.And a fth put the nickname down to cravings that mum felt during the pregnancy.The main reason  per cent of parents applied a nickname to a burgeoning bump was to stop having to refer to their unborn child as ‘it’.But one in  recall someone  using the nickname first, and then found themselves using it throughout the pregnancy.However, the silly name proved to be a source of embarrassment for  per cent, with many parents only using it with their partner – never in public.It also emerged two thirds believe giving a nickname to a baby bump helps parents-to-be bond with the child before it’s born, according to the research.

title: presidents day everything to know about washingstons birthday including stock market closures
story: But what does Presidents Day entail and what is its history  Heres everything you need to know.Presidents Day is a federal holiday in America celebrated on the third Monday in February.The holiday commemorates the birthday of George Washington, the first President of the United States born on February , .The holiday is also used to celebrate other presidents birthdays, most commonly Abraham Lincoln.Interestingly, because the  Unorm Monday Holiday Act dictated that the holiday had to fall between February  and February  each year, Presidents Day never actually falls on Washingtons birthday.Until the late s, most corporate businesses closed on Presidents Day like they would on Christmas Day.Now many remain open and run sales and promotions instead, while federal and state government services — including the U.S. Postal Service — do still close.Public elementary and secondary schools also generally shut, while many colleges and universities run amended timetables.The New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq will be closed with normal trading resuming on Tuesday February .The Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association also recommends that the United States bond market close on Presidents Day.Cherry pie is traditionally associated with Presidents Day based on the apocryphal legend of Washington chopping down his fathers cherry tree as a six-year-old child.The myth states that when Washingtons father confronted him about the tree, Washington replied: I cannot tell a lie... I did cut it with my hatchet.And the Purple Heart medal, bearing an image of Washington and awarded to those wounded or killed in battle, is given out on Presidents Day.Since , the United States Senate hears Washingtons Farewell Address read aloud by a member of the Senate on the Senate floor, alternating parties each year.

story: The battle sub - named Fateh- was launched by hardline President Hassan Rouhani in the port of Bandar Abbas and can hit targets , miles away.From this moment, the Fateh Submarine joins Irans naval force with my order, Rouhani said in a ceremony broadcast live on the state-run English-language Press TV.Reporters claimed the Fateh weighs  tonnes and enjoys state-of-the-art weaponry, including torpedoes, naval mines and cruise missiles that could be launched from a submerged position.President Donald Trump pulled out of a  nuclear agreement between Iran and six powers last May and reimposed sanctions on Tehran.He said the deal was flawed because it did not include curbs on Irans development of ballistic missiles or its support for proxies in Syria, Yemen, Lebanon and Iraq.Iran has developed a large domestic arms industry in the face of international pressure and embargoes that have barred it from importing many weapons.Our defence power is solely defensive...Our enemys pressure and sanctions imposed on Iran have instigated our progress, Rouhani said in the southern port city of Bandar Abbas.Last year, Irans navy launched a domestically-built destroyer, which state media said has radar-evading stealth properties.Iran says it has missiles with the range of up to , miles, which puts old enemy Israel and US military bases in the region within reach.The European signatories of Irans nuclear deal, despite remaining committed to the pact, have stepped up criticism of Irans ballistic missiles program.Last week, US Vice-President Mike Pence demanded EU allies withdraw from the Iran nuclear deal which had aimed to stop the Middle Eastern country developing nukes.Trumps second-in-command also accused its European partners of trying to break US sanctions against Tehran which have been slapped down on the Islamic Republic to force it to give up their weapons programme.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may to backtrack on brexit promises to mps and wont seek to re open deal minister reveals
story: Jeremy Wright said today that the PM might u-turn and simply accept legal changes to the deal instead, which has angered Leavers in the Tory party yet again.They have demanded that the hated Northern Ireland backstop be ripped out entirely, and refuse to accept any moderate tweaks to the deal.The Culture Secretary told the BBCs Andrew Marr Show this morning: I dont think its the mechanism that matters, its the objective.If you get to a place where the potential longevity of the backstop, the potential the backstop lasts forever can be dealt with, thats what we are all seeking to do.He said that ripping up the backstop in the withdrawal agreement was only one thing that was being looked at, but there are a number of dferent ways to stop it trapping us in the EU forever.But Mrs May told MPs on  January that her plans will involve re-opening the withdrawal agreement.She promised to go back to Brussels and beg them to re-open the deal - but admitted it would be a tricky task and they might not agree.Today MP Mark Francois told Sky News: If the EU arent willing to [re-open the deal] the withdrawal agreement wont go through. We will vote it down, its that simple.And he added: If the EU want to bully us, they will get absolutely nowhere.Coming back with a wishy washy guarantee would convince no-one to get behind her, he added.MP Steve Baker, who has said the EU have to insist on re-opening the deal, has admitted in leaked WhatsApp messages that he thinks the talks are now a complete waste of time.He thinks that the EU and UK are now working together to run down the block to force the deal through with few changes.Mr Wright stressed today that there were concerns about the potential indefinite nature of the backstop and ministers have got to do something about it.Parliament needs to give the PM the space to have that conversation with Brussels to see what we can achieve, he added.The PM is set to meet Jean Claude Juncker this week, and Brexit Secretary Steve Barclay will fly out for more talks with EU official tomorrow with the Attorney General.Last week The Sun reported that UK negotiators have indicated they will accept surgical tweaks to the Withdrawal Agreement rather than a full reopening of it.But Mr Barclay stressed changes outlining the temporary nature of the backstop must be legally binding to satisfy Geoffrey Cox and the DUP.EU sources were dismayed he was unable to say what new wording the UK wants on the backstop or what is needed to get the deal through the Commons.Jacob begged her colleagues to unite and deliver on Brexit so we can all move on as a country.In a letter to all MPs after her humiliating defeat last week on Valentines Day that she will speak to every single EU member states leader over the next few daysshe can.And Sir Graham Brady, who put down the amendment which united the Tory party just a few weeks ago, said the job has been made more dficult by the votes last week.But all is now lost and they should back the PM throwing all her energy into make sure that the backstop is replaced either by a rapid agreement about how the Irish border title: tony blair blasts jeremy corbyns chaotic brexit policy and says hes losing leave and remain votes
story: But the ex-PM said Labour MPs should stay in the party to focus on stopping Brexit with another referendum.He risked the fury of Brexiteers yet again by demanding that Labour should back a so-called Peoples Vote to persuade the country to stay in the EU.In an interview with the Sunday Times, Mr Blair said: I believe that we would be strongerwe did.The arch Remainer said: With this amount of negotiation and this level of mess at a certain point it’s not unreasonable to say to the people do you really want to proceed in these circumstances Oryou do want to proceed do you want a soft Brexit or a hard Brexit And on the leftie bosss confused position on Brexit he warned: The risk for Labour is that over time what has been described as constructive ambiguity becomes destructive indecision, losing votes from leave people who think you’re not really leave, and remain people who think you’re not really for remain.I don’t think it’s the right political strategy.The Labour boss has insisted that he wont try and overturn the referendum to keep his Brexit-voting members happy.But hes also said the option of another vote would be on the tableall other options are exhausted.Mr Corbyn has a history of eurosceptism and some of his close political allies are said to have voted to Leave - though Mr Corbyn says he opted to Remain.However, during the campaign he was accused of sitting back and not doing enough to help win over wavering Brexit voters.But now the nation is in peril Mr Blair claims - and theres no way of knowing what kind of future deal well end up with.

story: The Shadow Chancellor admitted he was in talks with MPs about a backbench amendment to force the PM to another voteher deal gets through - but alsoit didnt pass.That would mean that evenTheresa May forces it through Parliament then Brexit could all be at risk once again by putting it to the people.Our EU exit could be put on ice for months and even reversed completelythe MPs managed to force the change through.Leftie Mr McDonnell told the BBC this morning he would look at plans from MPs Peter Kyle and Phil Wilson to tag on a change to the agreement when it finally gets voted on again.They say it could break the Brexit impasse, but it would set Britain up for years more insecurity over leaving the EU.I met Peter and Phil last week, and what theyre saying isParliament does agree some form of deal, why not have a confirmation referendum after that  he told the Andrew Marr Show.Well look at that in the debate over the next week.And he also said that Labour could ask the people for another daythe deal DOESNT pass too.He added: If you cant get a deal agreed through parliament orany deal you thought wasnt going to protect jobs and the economy youd have to go back to the people and I think thats right.But Tories reacted furiously to the plans which would frustrate Brexit and leave the PMs plans up in their air.Brandon Lewis, Conservative Party Chairman, said earlier: With John McDonnell refusing six times to rule out a second referendum, its clear that Jeremy Corbyns Labour cannot be trusted to deliver on the decision of the British people.And he blasted: Yet again, its clear that Labour are frustrating Brexit and playing political games with it - turning their backs on their promise to implement the referendum result.Mrs May has repeatedly ruled out a second referendum, saying we must focus on delivering the result of the  historic vote.She said it would open the door for a third referendumno one respected the first one.Earlier Tony Blair said Mr Corbyns policy of being constantly on the fence was driving away both Leave voters AND Remainers as he again demanded a second Brexit vote.

title: mums world fell apart doctor
story: NewsMums world fell apart when doctor told her baby boy unlikely to ever walk or talkKelly Mansell and Robert Smith were devastated when doctors at Royal Derby Hospital told them their baby Teddy had a le-changing conditionShareByRichard CastleMilo Boyd:,  FEB NewsBaby Teddy, smiling despite his medical troubles"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum has told of the devastating moment her world fell apart when doctors revealed her baby boy was unlikely to ever walk or talk. Kelly Mansell and partner Robert Smith were lost for words when they were told little Teddy had a neurological illness called Aicardi-Goutiegraveres Syndrome. The condition is rare, affecting one in every  babies and hindering sufferers ability to send messages to and from their brains.Now Kelly,from Swadlincote, Derbyshire, has spoken bravely about the moment medics at Royal Derby Hospital broke the news, Derbyshire Live reported.  The -year-old said: The doctor came into the room and asked us to sit down. She told us Teddys brain didnt look like it should for a baby of his age and hadnt developed properly. She said I know you must have a lot of questions, like whether hell walk or talk again, but we just cant answer them at this stage. It felt like our world had fallen apart in that moment. We couldnt speak. I thought this isnt actually real - its a nightmare and Im going to wake up any minute. I asked myself why him . He was a little baby with his whole le ahead of him. I felt like hed been given this le sentence thats always going to be there and wont get better.   The formal diagnosis was made months later. Kelly struggled to go out and meet her friends, many of whom have children of a similar age to her -month-old son. She said: Seeing everything Teddy shouldve been doing was the hardest part. I stayed away from social media and all the pictures of children hitting these milestones, like starting to sit up or feed themselves. He wasnt doing any of those things - he was just lying there. Before they received the diagnosis the couples le with Teddy seemed perfect. In the eight weeks after Teddy was born weighing a healthy lbs at Lichfield Maternity Unit in September  the couple began to settle into their role as parents. Kelly had started planning milestones including his first trip to the park, holiday and day at school. She said: You just cant describe it - it was the most amazing thing. We were elated. Your whole world changes for the better in an instant and you cant wait to be a family. We were just full of joy with him at home with our new baby - just the most beautul, perfect boy. It was all so simple and exactly what youd expect. Youre up all night and changing nappies, but its great.   Their dream le encountered its first bump in the road when one night Teddy wouldnt wake up and showed little interest in feeding.Two overnight stays at Queens Hospitalin Burton resulted in a diagnosis of meningitis - a common finding for Aicardi-Goutiegraveres Syndrome sufferers due to their high white blood cell count.Things carried on as happily as they had done before until one shocking doctors appointment changed everything. Kelly said: I remember that Sunday so clearly - it was one of the worst days of my le. He started vomiting and making abnormal movements, with his eyes rolling back. It looked to us like he was having some sort of seizure. It was terrying. I still remember it as though Im living it now. We went into complete panic and I thought he was dying. Nothing can prepare you for something like that. Its so frightening. The fear of losing your baby is something you cant really describe. We rushed him into AE at Royal Derby Hospital and thats where he was diagnosed. Months later, maintenance engineer Robert, , and pharmaceutical worker Kelly are coming to terms with their situation. They have heaped praise on the amazing team at Royal Derby as well as Bowen Therapy practitioner Caroline Bark, who has helped develop Teddys muscles and nervous system.   Despite the good work of medical practitioners in the UK Teddy needs specialist help specic to his condition, which means treatment in America. In a bid to get their boy the best possible care Kelly and Robert are trying to raise pound, for two trips to the States - one for a consultation in Philadelphia and another to a therapy centre in Boston. They hope Teddy can join the trial for a drug called baricitinib, which cannot be prescribed for his condition in the UK. Kelly said: Hes doing things I would never have expected six months ago, like learning to smile and laugh. Hes actually a very happy little boy and has taught us so much, like not to take le for granted. Most people get up in the morning, walk downstairs and make breakfast - Teddy will never experience that. Were not expecting miracles, but we hopewe can get him to America he can reach his own milestones. If he can build up enough strength in his core to sit up, hold his head up for longer or feed himself, that will be an incredible achievement for him.To donate to the cause go to www.gofundme trust-in-ted

title: brexit news put people march
story: NewsBrexit news: Put it to the People march planned for week before withdrawalOgranised by the Peoples Vote campaign, it will call for the public to have the final say on the UKs exit from the EUShareCommentsByHarriet Line:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsDemonstrators marching last September "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCampaigners seeking a second referendum on Brexit have announced plans to hold a protest the weekend before the scheduled departure date.The Put it to the People march, organised by Peoples Vote, will call for the public to be given a final say on any Brexit deal.Its timing - on March  - follows suggestions that a deal may not be agreed until the eleventh hour. Britain is due to leave the European Union on March . Pro-Remain MPs from across the Commons welcomed the announcement, with Tory former minister Anna Soubry saying there will be nowhere for any MP to hide come the final week of March.   She said: There is now a real danger that this is going to go right down to the wire. The Prime Minister appears intent on holding the long-awaited meaningful vote as late as possible, in the hope of pressuring MPs into backing what they know is a bad deal.And Jeremy Corbyn appears happy to let the clock run down, rather than tabling Labours proposals or backing a Peoples Vote.But come the final week of March there will be nowhere for any MP to hide, which is why this march could be of historic signicance. Parliament will need a way out, and the demand will be loud and clear: put short term party politics aside, put Britains national interest first. Put it to the people.  Liberal Democrat leader Sir Vince Cable predicted hundreds of thousands of people would take to the streets to demand their voices are heard.The Governments handling of Brexit has become a national humiliation. They, along with the Labour leadership, want to kick the can down the road, but people across the country will not stand idly by whilst they try to duck the biggest political decision in a generation. Crunch time is coming.I know that hundreds of thousands of people from right across the United Kingdom will take to the streets and join us in demanding that their voices are heard - that the only way forward out of this Brexit mess is through a Peoples Vote.SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford echoed the belief that the Prime Minister will wait until the final week to tell MPs we have to have a bad or blindfold deal or accept no deal. He added: It is a scandal and we will not accept it. Scotland voted to Remain and we will do everything we can to make sure that all the people of the four nations in the UK have the chance to have the final say on Brexit. Ill be in the march, joining together with people from north and south of the border, in an act of national solidarity against this clear and present danger to all our futures.   Green Party co-leader Caroline Lucas added: This is High Noon for Brexit. This march is for all those who are concerned about the way politics is descending into chaos, and for those who feel let down by broken Brexit promises. Whether youre worried about the damage caused by this deal or no deal, or you just want clarity and closure about our countrys direction - rather than years more of argument and ision - join us. By working together, we can fix this mess.

Writing in the Sun on Sunday, Mr Dugher said the Labour party had repeatedly failed to adequately tackle anti-Semitism. The now chief executive of UK Music said: I will continue to have lots of dear friends in the Labour Party, including many talented MPs and hard-working local councillors who are fantastically dedicated public servants. Yet in all good conscience, I can no longer justy paying subs to a party which I now regard as institutionally anti-Semitic.   He said situations where prominent Jewish Labour MPs - Ruth Smeeth and Luciana Berger - needed police protection made him want to cry, and expressed concern at the attitude of shadow chancellor John McDonnell after Ms Berger was facing a vote of no confidence from her local party. Mr McDonnell insisted again on Sunday that the move to censure the MP was due to concern she may join a breakaway party, not over her attacks on Jeremy Corbyns handling of anti-Semitism. Mr McDonnell said that stamping out anti-Semitism from the party had become a mission for him. And he insisted that the party had a no tolerance policy towards anti-Semitism.  Labour disclosed this week it had received  allegations of anti-Semitism by its members over the past  months, leading to  iniduals being expelled. A party spokesman said the numbers involved amounted to around .% of the total membership roll, but added: One anti-Semite in our party is one too many.Jeremy Corbyn came under intense pressure last year over allegations that under his leadership Labour had not taken enough action to deal with anti-Semitic remarks and behaviour among its ranks.In September, the ruling National Executive Committee adopted the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliances definition in full, after coming under attack for initially omitting some of its examples of anti-Semitic behaviour.

title: minister says pm might not
story: NewsMinister says PM might not ask for Brexit Withdrawal Agreement to be reopenedJeremy Wright implied the insurance policy to prevent a hard border could be amended via a codicil, saying the "objective" mattered more than the "mechanism"ShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  FEB News "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Prime Minister may not seek to reopen the Brexit Withdrawal Agreement to make changes to the controversial Irish backstop, a Cabinet minister has suggested. Jeremy Wright implied the insurance policy to prevent a hard border could be amended via a codicil, saying the objective mattered more than the mechanism. But the Brexit-supporting European Research Group within the Tory party have already indicated they wont support a deal which relies on a codicil or addendum to impose a time limit or allow the UK to exit the backstop unilaterally.Mr Wrights controversial comments came hours after Theresa May wrote to Tory MPs assuring them the Government would continue its work to secure changes to the backstop, as she pleaded with them to unite and deliver on Brexit .Mr Wright told the BBCs Andrew Marr Show: I think whats obvious is that Parliament, and I think probably people well beyond Parliament, are concerned about the potential indefinite nature of the backstop - thats what weve got to do something about. If this is the only way of doing it then thats the way we will pursue. If there are other ways of doing it that are just as effective that perhaps we havent yet explored then we will do that too.  He continued: I dont think its the mechanism that matters, its the objective:you can get to a place where the potential longevity of the backstop, the potential that the backstop lasts forever can be adequately dealt with, thats what were all It On Friday a Number  Spokeswoman insisted that the Prime Minister was seeking to reopen the agreement to change its wording. She said: We have said we are seeking legally binding changes to the backstop which is contained within the Withdrawal Agreement. Former Brexit minister Steve Baker has told colleagues Mrs Mays Brexit negotiations with Brussels were a complete waste of time. He said of the backstop: Only a treaty-level clause which confers an unconditional right on the UK to exit the backstop would work. Meanwhile Defence Minister Tobias Ellwood urged the Government to allow a free vote on ruling out a no-deal Brexit at the end of the monthMrs May cannot get her deal through the Commons.   He told BBC Radio  Lives Pienaars Politics he would support such a vote, saying: I will intend to do that. I hope I will not be tested in that way. I hope that we will either get the meaningful vote through or indeed measures are taken which will then allow people like myself to then express those through a free vote. Brexit Minister Chris Heaton-Harris has insisted the Government is not trying to run down the clock on Brexit. He dismissed suggestions that the negotiations are a complete waste of time, and said there was a huge amount of activity between the UK and Brussels. Mr Heaton-Harris told Sky News: The Government is not trying to run the clock down. The Government is trying to get a negotiated deal with our European partners. On Saturday, Mrs May urged her party to move beyond what ides us and sacrice personal preferences for the national interest. After another tumultuous week in Westminster which saw tensions in the party reach boiling point, Mrs May used a letter to all  Conservative MPs to warn them: History will judge us all for the parts we have played in this process.  She said: I believe that a country with our innate strengths, enviable resources, and enormous talent can face the future with confidence that our best days lie ahead. But we stand now at a crucial moment. I do not underestimate how deeply or how sincerely colleagues hold the views which they do on this important issue - or that we are all motivated by a common desire to do what is best for our country, evenwe disagree on the means of doing so. But I believe that a failure to make the compromises necessary to reach and take through Parliament a Withdrawal Agreement which delivers on the result of the referendum will let down the people who sent us to represent them and risk the bright future that they all deserve. The Prime Minister willto Brussels for further talks with European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker this week, and intends to speak to the leaders of every EU member state over the coming days. Meanwhile, Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay will meet the EUs chief negotiator Michel Barnier on Monday to discuss the proposals of the Alternative Arrangements Working Group of Tories, who have been seeking a compromise solution to avoid the need for backstop. And Attorney General Geoffrey Cox will set out what changes would be required to eliminate the legal risk of being indefinitely trapped in the controversial Irish backstop in a speech on Tuesday.

title: tory brexiteers say theyll vote
story: NewsTory Brexiteers say theyll vote for Mays EU deal - onlyshe steps down as PMEXCLUSIVE: Jacob Rees-Mogg’s rebel European Research Group want her to quit as PM after local elections on May  as the price for their supportShareCommentsByNigel NelsonPolitical Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThe European Research Group say they will vote for Mays EU deal in Parliamentshe steps down as PM after local elections "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory Brexiteers are plotting to demand Theresa May’s job as the price to push through her EU deal. Jacob Rees-Mogg’s rebel European Research Group want her to quit as PM after local elections on May . Inthey will vote for her deal in Parliament so she can hit her March  deadline for the UK to leave the EU. A Tory leadership contest would take place over the summer – with the ERG backing their champion, Boris Johnson. The new PM would be crowned at the Tory Party conference in September.  The plotters calculate they can hold Mrs May to ransom because she cares more about getting Brexit on her terms than she does about being PM.An insider said: “The PM believes in getting things done – and there’s nothing bigger than delivering Brexit. “If she can pull that off she’ll have her legacy. And she’ll feel her work is done.” EU negotiators are adamant they will not reopen the withdrawal agreement, which includes the controversial “Irish backstop” to protect the open border. But they have indicated they can give legal assurances, to appease Brexiteers, that the measure will be temporary. As things stand at least  hardcore ERG backbenchers will not back Mrs May’s deal – either with or without changes to the backstop. Butthey think they can get Boris for PM, it is expected they will back down.With the ERG on board, and  Labour rebels who Mrs May is trying to bribe with cash for their constituencies, the PM will have enough votes to get across the line.And she will be home and drythe DUP come back on board. But Lib Dem Jo Swinson, the Employment Relations minister in David Cameron’s coalition government, today warns Labour MPs not to be fooled by the PM’s pledges on worker rights.

title: voice mirror jeremy corbyn prime
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Jeremy Corbyn as Prime Minister is still our best optionReservations about some of Mr Corbyn’s twists and turns may remain but a Labour government led by him is still in our best interestsShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  FEB NewsopinionWe understand Labour MPs frustrations with Jeremy Corbyn "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe hairline fractures running through the bones of the British body politic are on the brink of becoming full-scale breaks. Theresa May’s party is fast smashing itself beyond repair. The increasingly eccentric behaviour of Jacob Rees-Mogg’s Brexiteer rebels means not even a bodycast would keep the Conservatives intact. And Mrs May’s appeal for unity today will fall on deaf ears. If there were a General Election tomorrow, the PM would find herself in the extraordinary position of campaigning against her own party. And Tory MPs would have to speak out against their leader. That is why an election is unlikely. But in the chaos that is Westminster nowadays, it’s not impossible. Which is also why Labour must be prepared for it. And for the few MPs tempted to break away from Jeremy Corbyn to think again. Opinion polls suggest that Labour and the Tories are running neck and neck. For Labour MPs to turn their backs on their party would be to snatch a catastrophic defeat from the jaws of a slender victory.   We understand the frustration of these MPs. The threat of deselection hangs over them. Mr Corbyn has still not got to grips with anti-semitism. They may well feel he should stop sitting on the fence over Brexit, but the fence is not a bad place to be while the Labour leader sees which side of it the Tories come down on. This newspaper has reservations about some of Mr Corbyn’s twists and turns. But we believe a Labour government led by him is still in the best interests of Sunday Mirror readers. It would be a tragedya handful of MPs besotted by Brexit were to jeopardise that. Sunday Mirror readers would never forgive them. A duty to pubs Philip Hammond might argue that the pub trade has never had it so good. The Chancellor froze beer duty for the second year running in his last Budget. And in giving businesses with rateable values below pound, a tax break, he saved the landlord of a typical Sheffield pub more than pound, a year. But pubs are a special case. They are the soul of both urban and rural communities. They may be closing down at a slower rate than they were, but we are still losing  a week and that is unacceptable.   And at p a pint, UK beer duty remains the third highest in Europe. The Campaign for Real Ale says Brexit presents an opportunity to create a level playing field between pubs and supermarkets and off licences. We heartily agree. And so should the Chancellor as he pieces together Britain’s post-Brexit economy. Pubs should enjoy a special status when Mr Hammond works out which sectors get what tax break. Just as they enjoy a special place in the nation’s heart.

title: pregnant teen universal credit faced
story: NewsPregnant teen on Universal Credit faced starvation - then something incredible happenedJaedyn Overbury and Lizzie Mason were struggling on Universal Credit after moving out of a Birmingham YMCAShareByStephanie BallooMilo Boyd:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video struggling-universal-credit-teen-feared-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A teen couple expecting their first baby were fearing weeks of hunger on Universal Credit before something amazing happeed.Jaedyn Overbury and Lizzie Mason, both , hit hard times after moving out of a YMCA homeless shelter and into a house share in Erdington, Birmingham.The cash-strapped couple lived off dry toast for three days after Jaedyn was signed off sick from his job stacking shelves atASDA with General Anxiety Disorder, Birmingham Live reports.The pound they received each month through Universal Credit soon vanished on rent, smart price food, phone top-ups and public transport back and forth to hospital appointments.   With weeks of nothing but a few slices of bread stretching out in front of the engaged couple and their unborn baby, Jaedyn put out a desperate plea to their new community. The response from kind-hearted locals was astonishing. As soon as his request for advice about food banks began to circulate online residents rallied together to donate a huge hamper of food. Where before they had the bare essentials, the couple quickly found themselves with a fridge full of bacon, fruit, soup, pasta, crisps, bread and dozens of tins, as well as eggs, milk, butter and cheese. The pair said the food haul will last them up to two months and will help four-weeks pregnant Lizzie to enjoy a healthy pregnancy.   Jaedyn said: I was amazed by the response we got, we didnt expect it at all. We had food from about three people, picked up by one of the ladies and dropped to us all on the first night that we had put the post up. And then from there to yesterday we have had four more people drop food to us. While doctors have recommended that the teen should not work at the moment, he is still looking for a job to make ends meet.   Jaedyn continued: The universal rate for being signed off is awful to live on so Im still looking for part time work, even when advised by the doctors not to be in work for the time being. I struggle quite badly with Generalized Anxiety Disorder and I also have problems with my chest and breathing which makes physical tasks dficult, still waiting on x-ray and blood results to figure out why my breathing is so limited. I can barely make it up a set of stairs without gasping for air so any physically job wouldnt work. As well as the food the couple received plenty of advice as to which food banks to go to and how to get vouchers.   Jaedyns heartbreaking appeal on the Erdington community group on Sunday, February  read: Me and my misses are new to areaand we have been here for about four months now. We have moved into a house share of four people and unfortunately due to having a shared kitchen keep having our food vanish out the freezer. We have informed our support staff but they can only recommend calling policeWe have completely run out of food and we dont get any money between us until Thursday . We want to know where the nearest food bank is and how to get vouchers for it  My misses is pregnant and I dont want her to go without anything to eat for the next week, possibly month. We are really struggling with finding something to eat. We both dont have contact with family and no friends in the area, its just the two of us.

title: spooky sightings vomiting space truth
story: NewsSpooky sightings and vomiting in space, the truth about le as an astronautAstronaut Don Thomas, , went to space  times in his career with NASA...ShareByemma jones:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsDon launches on his first mission, STS-, on  July  "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNothing quite prepares you for that first look at planet Earth from space. The first thing that struck me was how thin our atmosphere is.It’s not the sprawling, beautul blue sky we’re used to, it’s paper-thin. Then the blackness of space, darker than you can ever imagine. There isn’t one astronaut who doesn’t have their nose pressed against the window, awestruck. When I was six, on  May , the US launched the first American astronaut into space. My school had us all watching it on a small black and white TV. That moment changed my le forever – I was determined to one day go into space. Space exploration is one of the most competitive careers ever, and when the application process opens every couple of years, only a handful are selected.    A physics degree is the minimum to get in, so I got a masters and doctorate in engineering, but it still wasn’t enough. I was turned down three times. Only when I got my pilot’s licence, learnt to sky e and got a job at NASA did I finally get through. My fourth attempt, at  years old. I’ll never forget the moment I was told I’d been signed up for my first space mission. I was working in Mission Control, talking to the astronauts up in space, when I got the call – I would be in the next mission going up in two years. I hung up the phone and wanted to scream, but I still had another seven hours of work before I could get in my car and really let go! By the time my first flight came along, I’d been training for four years for one -day mission. NASA prepares us for everything, the idea being to have all the experiences on Earth, so there are no surprises in space. We fly in jet aircraft and special planes capable of creating -second periods of zero-gravity. We train underwater for space walks. We also undergo extensive, continual medical checks.   Everyone on the mission is trained to have a unique skill – I was responsible for the science experiments on board Then two astronauts on every mission are ex-military test pilots, responsible for flying and landing the shuttle.Two people are also intensively trained to be able to do everything, in case someone gets sick. But we all have basic knowledge – let’s just say I could land us home, just not all that well! One thing NASA doesn’t want is anyone getting sick. A week before launch we’re in quarantine. We have to eat carefully prepared food, so we don’t risk poisoning.Every person we come in contact with has had a full check – we can’t risk getting a cold.The space sickness is bad enough, which around a third of astronauts suffer from, puking their guts up from motion sickness. You can imagine what vomit does up there… Not pleasant.  Launch morning on my first mission was the most exciting day of my le. I was lying on my back, strapped in on top of a lumpy parachute, where I lay for three hours before take off.Then I heard the countdown, and three big engines started rumbling up to full power, causing the spacecraft and me to shake.At lt off I felt a push, assomeone had their hand on the small of my back, hoisting me up. I was screaming like I was on a roller-coaster because I knew nobody could hear me, not even the seven other astronauts I was going up with.Of course there was some fear, but it’s % nerves and % exhilaration. Not for my we, though, who told me she hated that launch morning more than anything. It takes eight and a half minutes to get into space,  miles above the Earth. It becomes eerily silent once you make it.Then you unstrap yourself and float out of your seat. We orbit the Earth every half an hour, and see  sunrises and sunsets every day. On my first ever day in space, I looked out of the window and a flash caught my eye. Every second it would go, getting closer and closer.I couldn’t believe on my first day in space I’d made contact with the unknown! But my alien turned out to be a chunk of ice that had come off the shuttle and was flashing every time it hit sunlight.Another amazing sight was a giant ball of light flashing past. A shooting star. Of course I made a wish – to get home safely. My first mission was to further explore the effects of zero gravity on liquids and fire. Liquids form perfectly round balls, and fire also becomes either droplets or big fire balls too.We take plants and small animals up to observe how they grow and behave. Since then we’ve done plenty of other experiments.  We work -hour days with - hours sleep , an hour for lunch and dinner, and a free hour for exercise.We have magnetic chess sets, and we love playing human catch – one of the crew tucks themselves into a ball and we throw him to each other.As for human contact, it’s important to have communication with home. Whenever we passed over America, I always felt a million miles away, like I was detached from my le.I could send and receive one short email from my we each day, and once during a two week mission she was allowed in Mission Control to speak with me on the phone. When the mission was finally over, getting back is the easy bit. You slow down, turn the shuttle around, fire up the engines and start falling so fast that you can see flames as the atmosphere hits around , degrees.We landed smoothly and were welcomed with a huge lunch at NASA – lasagne, salad and cookies – before they flew us home.After I’d hugged my we, the first thing I did was order a pepperoni pizza. The space food is bland – by the end of a mission I couldn’t wait to eat good food. There are many amazing things about being an astronaut, but you have to savour every second of space time – during my  years, I only spent  days in space.One downside of being home is flying on a plane is now extremely slow and boring. I resent how it takes me nine hours to get to England from America – it could be done in  minutes! It also ruins space movies. Gravity drove me crazy. Even in the opening scene I was saying, ‘They’ve got that wrong!’ Now I’m too old for space travel and have retired, but I teach children of the wonders of space every day. When you’ve had an adrenaline rush like space travel, it’s hard to know what’s next. My dream is to receive a call from someone who I’ve inspired to follow in my footsteps. Don is an ambassador for Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex, Florida, the best place on Earth for space . A one-day pass costs from pound per adult pound per child. Also included is the chance to have lunch with a real astronaut. VisitAttraction-tickets-direct

title: surrogate mum tells how gave
story: NewsSurrogate mum tells how she gave birth to twins - after using her WIFES eggsEXCLUSIVE: Lesbian couple Hayley and Kirsty Bensberg Hickmott wanted to both be involved in starting their family – so came up with an unusual solutionShareCommentsByAntonia Paget:,  FEB NewsHayley Bensberg Hickmott and we Kirsty we had their family dream come true "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A loving couple pose for a pic at a baby shower hours before becoming parents – and there’s tumthing truly special about their story.For Hayley Bensberg Hickmott and we Kirsty were BOTH about to become mums, even though only one of them was pregnant. The couple, who met while working at the same hospital, found the answer to their dream through shared motherhood. Kirsty, , wanted her own biological child, but didn’t want to be pregnant – while Hayley wanted to be pregnant, but didn’t mindthe child wasn’t genetically hers. So they hit on the perfect,unusual, solution. Doctors would take eggs from Kirsty, fertilise them with an anonymous sperm donor – and then Hayley would carry the couple’s baby. Or, as it turned out, BABIES – as the embryo that was put into Hayley’s womb split, creating identical twins.  There would be heartache and anxiety along the way, but when Hayley gave birth to sons Dylan and Stanley  months ago, their family was complete. Hayley, , said: “People are amazed to hear that it was Kirsty’s eggs and that I was the one who carried the boys. It was a perfect solution for us. “She wanted to have children but didn’t want to be pregnant herself and I didn’t mindthe child I carried wasn’t genetically mine. I have trained as a midwe and I’ve always wanted to be pregnant. So that’s how we decided on how we were going to create our family.” The couple, who live in Kent, met five years ago at a local hospital when Hayley was an AE nurse and Kirsty was a paramedic. Hayley added: “We really hitoff when we met, but we didn’t become a couple for six months. “As soon as I met Kirsty, I knew that she was going to be in my le somehow. “We married in September , then started to look at starting our family.”  The couple had fertility treatment at a private clinic in Southampton. Kirsty had to inject herself daily with drugs to stimulate her oies to produce eggs, which were fertilised with donor sperm. One embryo was put back into Hayley’s womb, but two weeks later, the couple found the treatment had failed. Hayley said: “It was devastating when it hadn’t worked the first time. But we were determined to carry on and not give up hope.” They had a second attempt at fertility treatment in February  – and this time it worked. But they were in for a double surprise when they went for her first scan.  Hayley went on: “We were thrilled when we found out we were expecting twins. We couldn’t believe it when the sonographer showed us two little heartbeats pumping away. It was amazing.” But things did not run smoothly. When Hayley was  weeks pregnant, doctors found the babies were suffering from a rare, le-threatening condition called Twin to Twin Transfusion Syndrome. It affects only identical twins and occurs when abnormal blood flow in the vessels joining the babies means that one gets more nutrients than the other. It can put too much strain on the bigger twin’s heart and it can mean the smaller baby doesn’t get enough nutrients. The condition puts the le of both babies in peril. Hayley said: “We were devastated when we were told that the twins had it. “The following week I started getting very breathless and filling up with fluid, so they knew something had to be done.”   Hayley was referred to King’s College Hospital in London under the care of world-renowned surgeon Professor Kypros Nicolaides. He operated to separate the twins by laser surgery while they were still in Hayley’s womb. “It was frightening to think they were going to be operated on while I was still pregnant,” Hayley said. “But we knew it was their only chance of survival. And even then we didn’t knowthey were going to survive the surgery.” After the operation, there was a risk that she could miscarry the twins. Only a week later she suffered a massive bleed and had to be rushed back into hospital. But the twins were hanging on – and survived. Hayley then suffered bleeding through the rest of her pregnancy until the twins were finally delivered when she was  weeks pregnant. Stanley weighed in at Ib oz and Dylan was Ib oz. Hayley said: “It was such a relief when they were born safely. We had just been to a baby shower and an hour after we got home, I went into labour. We had to go straight into hospital and the boys were delivered. “Stanley was fine when he was born but Dylan was quite poorly and he had to be on oxygen for four months.” Hayley also suffered postnatal depression after the Caesarean birth and found it dficult to bond properly with the twins for the first eight months. She explained: “It was a strain, but it has brought Kirsty and I closer together. I had treatment for it and, after about eight months, I felt I could love the twins. “They are both doing really well now and are really healthy. “Other people are amazed when we tell them how we have done it, that genetically the boys are Kirsty’s, yet I gave birth to them.” Professor Simon Fishel, from Care Fertility, said: “It’s a very special way to start a family. Shared motherhood is quite a new option for lesbian couples. One woman’s egg is fertilised to create an embryo. Her partner can then carry their baby. This way both women feel totally involved.”

title: 7 things check your wee
story: News things to lookout for in your wee - as they could be signs of cancerProstate cancer is the most common cancer in men in the UK, and while many of the symptoms dont appear for years there are certain things to look out forShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsIts very important to check for these signs "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne in two people in the UK will get cancer at some point in their lives, an absolutely terrying statistic. While many types of the vile disease come with few symptoms, others have signs which can help identy it as quickly as possible. Prostate cancer is the most common cancer in men in the UK. The causes are unknown, but the chances of developing it increase as you get older. It develops slowly, and many men dont see any symptoms for years. It isnt until the prostate becomes large enough to affect the tube which carries urine out of the bladder and out of the penis that some of the tell-tell signs start to appear.  According to the NHS , there are seven things all men should be checking for in their wee which could be a tell-tell sign of the disease.They are:Needing to pee more frequently, often during the night Needing to rush to the toilet Dficulty in starting to peeStraining or taking a long time while peeing Weak flow Feeling that your bladder has not emptied fully Blood in urine or semenThere are a number of tests which can help diagnose prostate cancer, all of which your doctor should be able to arrange. They are a blood test, a physical prostate examination, and MRI or a biopsy. If the disease is caught early it can be treated through radiotherapy or surgery to remove it. Howeverit isnt caught until later it can spread to other parts of the body. Experts dont know why, but prostate cancer is more common in men of African-Caribbean or African descent and Asian men are less likely to be affected.

title: australian beaches close after great
story: NewsAustralian beaches close after great white shark takes chunk out of surfers legA friend of a victim described how suspected Great White took a big chunk out of his leg and left him heavily bleedingShareByFred Nathan:,  FEB NewsBeaches have closed near Byron Bay in Australia following a shark attack "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBeaches have been closed in the popular Australian surfing paradise of Byron Bay after a shark attacked a man, taking a chunk out of his leg. Sam Edwardes, was surfing near Belongil Beach, around about .am this morning when he was bitten by the toothy predator. The surfer, who was heavily bleeding, managed to fend off the shark and swim to shore while clinging to his surf board. He suffered shocking injuries to his upper thigh, according to eyewitnesses. Members of the public tried to treat Mr Edwardes as he lost pints of blood while they waited for emergency services to arrive.   His flatmate described his horror in graphic detail, explaining how the pair had just entered the water and were paddling out close to shore when the shark struck. He said: “Keen for a wave this morning, went for a surf and had literally only just paddled out of the water. “I was about  metres behind him , he sat up on his board and instantly a shark smashed up from underneath and knocked him clean off his board.   “There was a lot of thrashing and splashing. He started screaming, we didn’t realise until we paddled back to the beach that there was a big chunk taken out of his leg. “There was a lot of blood, a lot of bleeding. The bleeding was pretty bad. We didn’t see the shark but a bloke who was out there earlier said he saw a fin and he reckons it was a juvenile Great White.   “I was freaking. When I heard the screams he was making in the water and then I saw a chunk of his board floating off, that’s when I realised it was pretty bad. “He was conscious but … his eyes were drting around a bit, he seemed a bit dizzy. “He was saying his breathing was labouring … overall I think he was alright, he was just in a bit of shock.”   The attack has prompted surf le-saving crews to patrol beaches around the touristic hotspot of Byron Bay, with beaches having been closed for the past  hours. The attack comes just a day after a -year-old surf leguard disappeared while swimming at a nearby beach.

title: bargain brazilian bum lift turkey
story: NewsBargain Brazilian bum lt in Turkey left woman needing a le-saving operationEXCLUSIVE: Nightmare began for Brit Kianna, , after she traveled to have bum op inspired by Kim KardashianShareCommentsByPhil Cardy:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsFormer bum op patient Kianna Kinsella is warning others against cheap plastic surgery "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A British woman flew to Turkey for a pound, op to give her a fuller bum but ended up in an NHS bed when things went seriously pear-shaped.Kianna Kinsella, , developed a le-threatening abscess after having a Brazilian bum lt. Instead of celebrating a curvy new butt she had to face more surgery to remove the two-inch sore on her right buttock. The abscess — caused by fat necrosis, where cells in fatty tissue die — was on the brink of turning septic. Now Kianna is warning other women to think carefully before going for the same “flatter tum, bigger bum” procedure.  The beautician said: “I thought I’d done all the research, checked everything out. “The place had five-star reviews. But things can go badly wrong. If I had another pound, I wish I could go back to the way I was.” Single Kianna, of Runcorn, Cheshire, had been wooed by a clinic boasting “fine craftsmanship of Turkish doctors”. She was treated at a private clinic in Istanbul and her pound, — including flights and transfers — looked to be a bargain compared to the pound, she could have paid for the same op in the UK.  The procedure is popular among women wanting to reshape the buttocks by transferring fat from other areas of the body.But Kianna said far from trying to emulate the likes of reality star Kim Kardashian , she was doing it purely because she was uncomfortable with her size  body.She said: “I wanted a flatter tummy and bigger bum. I did all the research online, I could have done it cheaper, but I went for a place that got five-star reviews. “I could have had implants, but I read using your own fat was safer. “I’d read about a poor British girl who died in Turkey last year after shygoing for a bum lt, but I’d done all the research. “I thought I’d done everything right. I saved for three years, I spent that time doing research. I thought I’d got the best.” Kianna booked with MCAN Health, flew out last month and was put up in a five-star hotel in the centre of Istanbul.  She went on: “When we were picked up from the airport there were three guys in the minibus with me. They weren’t English but I think they were over for treatment too. The hotel was lovely. “I had to get up at am the next morning and the driver picked me and another girl up. She was dropped at one place and I was taken to my clinic.” Kianna was booked in at the Osmanoglu Hastanesi centre and expected plush premises to match images online. But she says the reality was very dferent: “It looked a bit old to me, I was expecting a modern, fancy place. “I’d already paid a  euro deposit so I handed over the other , euros. They didn’t give me a receipt.   “The room was pretty basic — bed, cabinet, shower. I felt uncomfortable because no one seemed to speak English. “When the doctor came to meet me he was more interested in my tattoos. They were all speaking to each other in Turkish while drawing on me with the marker pen.” Despite her misgivings, Kianna had the five-hour procedure on January  and said when she woke up she was “in pain everywhere”.She said: “I lay in the bed shaking, my boobs were out and there was no blanket to cover me. I had to use Google translate to ask a nurse ‘please will you get a vest for me’.I’m normally quite easy going, but I felt like I was being shyignored. I was bruised, swollen, on my own, upset and crying, which really isn’t me.” After one night at the clinic, she spent a further two nights at a hotel and then had a check-up with her surgeon. That showed “normal healing” and she flew home. But two weeks later her buttock became lumpy and sore. She was also disappointed by the “flatter shystomach” procedure – saying she has been left with a “square shape” on her tummy. Kianna messaged her MCAN aftercare team and claimed they told her to use Arnica gel — a herbal remedy for relieving pain and inflammation — and to apply a cold compress. But on February  she went to an NHS walk-in centre after the wound got worse.She was sent to Warrington Hospital where she was diagnosed with an infected abscess. Kianna was told she was at risk of le-threatening sepsis had the wound been left much longer.  The next day she had surgery to shyremove the abscess and was in hospital for three nights. She is on antibiotics, needs two weeks rest and fears she may be left scarred. She was full of praise for the NHS staff and added: “The doctors and nurses in Warrington were amazing, they weren’t judgmental in any way. “They didn’t tell me it was all self-inflicted or ask why I went abroad. I thought they would be saying ‘look at that silly cow’, but they were just brilliant.”  Now Kianna is urging others to think carefully before going abroad for cosmetic surgery. She warned: “I’d urge anyone to think carefully about what they’re having done andthey really need it. If I had the money I’d go back to the way I was.” Kianna said she sent pictures of her abscess to MCAN and was told it was due to fat necrosis. MCAN’s website boasts: “A Brazilian butt lt in Istanbul: this is where the West really meets the East! The fine craftsmanship of Turkish medical doctors is famous. You will find Turkish surgeons in JCI-accredited hospitals all over the world. But in Turkey the prices of cosmetic surgery are much lower. That makes often expensive treatments within reach for a much wider population.” MCAN has offered Kianna free corrective surgery – but she has no intention of ing. A spokesman said: “We hope Kianna will get well soon and all we can do is support her as much as we can. “As we stated to Kianna, complications are very rare and shyunfortunately it shyhappened to her. We will communicate with her doctor and support her as much as we can. “If she needs any corrective surgery, this will be free of charge.” But she said: “I wouldn’t go back to the clinic for surgerymy le depended on it.”

title: couples dream holiday turns nightmare
story: NewsCouples dream holiday turns into nightmare after travel firms airport blunderMarion and Robert Doogan had saved up for a year for the holiday of a letime to Turkey - but when they turned up at the airport, staff said noShareCommentsByFred Nathan:,  FEB NewsMarion and Robert Doogan have spoke of their shambles holiday of a letime "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA couples holiday of a letime became a case of blunder after blunder when travel firms Thomas Cook and TUI messed up which airport they were meant to be flying from. Marion and Robert Doogan had booked the fortnights trip to the luxury Turkish resort of Antalya a year in advance and meticulously planned every detail.They even paid through the nose for upgraded airport loungers and transfers to make their journey smoother, reports the Daily Record .But the holiday began on a bad note when they turned up at the check-in desk at Glasgow Airport, they were told their flight was from Edinburgh. Marion, , said: “We had tickets which clearly said Glasgow on them. But the girl at the desk shook her head. There were no flights to Turkey from Glasgow for three days.”   Airport staff contacted travel agent TUI, who had booked the pound Thomas Cook holiday. Sheltered housing boss Marion added: “The TUI shop insisted we were departing from Glasgow. Thomas Cook said they had told TUI otherwise. It was a shambles. No one had thought to tell us anything. “So Robert phoned our son and asked him to take us to Edinburgh. “We bundled our cases into our son’s car. We didn’t know whether we would catch the flight or not. “Staff at Edinburgh Airport were supposed to be waiting for us but when we got there, no one knew we were coming.” But Marion and Robert, , an assessor for the Scottish Qualications Authority, breathed a sigh of relief when did did make their flight and it took off for Turkey.   She said: “Our pre-booked seats were gone and there was no airport lounge but at least we were on board.” But further chaos ensued when they arrived in Antalya and were stranded again. Marion said: “We had paid extra for an upgraded private transfer. But there was no one to meet us.” Marion complained to TUI and Thomas Cook again and finally a transfer to the all-inclusive Barut Hemera complex was arranged. But Marion said: “We didn’t get to the hotel until .am when we’d left Edinburgh at .pm. This was hardly the relaxing start to the holiday we had planned.” The confusion continued during their break. She said: “We had no idea whether we were on an Edinburgh or a Glasgow flight home. No one could tell us.”   They flew back to Glasgow and submitted a claim to TUI and Thomas Cook. Marion said: “I wanted a refund for the lounge and pre-booked seats. I also demanded that they cover our outlays and offer something for the stress.” But she called me in when she was getting nowhere. She said: “I have been trying since we got home on September . But they are blaming each other. I am not going to let this drop.” Thomas Cook said they had told TUI about the flight change  months in advance. They added: “We are sorry this information did not reach Mr and Mrs Doogan. It was TUI’s responsibility to ensure the customers were notied.” TUI apologised and said: “We are in contact with them to resolve the matter.”

title: im celebs harry redknapp gives
story: NewsIm A Celebs Harry Redknapp gives eviction notice to needy tenants for huge property dealEXCLUSIVE:  vulnerable people, who live at the Belgravia hotel in Bournemouth, could be forced on to the streets by May - after the millionaire served them eviction noticesShareCommentsByAlan Selby:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsHarry Redknapp has served an eviction notice to the Belgravia Hotel in Bournemouth in a bid to convert the property into luxury flats "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Millionaire Harry Redknapp has come under fire for leaving  vulnerable bedsit shytenants facing homelessness as his company makes a fortune on a property deal.Their worried landlady called on him to cough up some of his pound, winnings from I’m A Celebrity to save them from a le on the streets. Good Samaritan Wendy Hunt, whorents the property and sub-lets rooms to the destitute at the Belgravia Hotel in Bournemouth, has been served an eviction notice by the former soccer boss. It means she and her tenants must be gone by May  so work can start on converting the building into money-spinning luxury flats.Wendy, , said: “I’ve got  people here. All of them will be homeless . We did try to get Harry to give them something to help them, but that was turned down.“A lot of them are vulnerable. They’ve been here years. I took them without deposits because they were on the streets, so now they won’t have money for a deposit somewhere new. “Can’t he do something with the money he won on I’m a Celebrity  He got a lot for that, on top of the money he’s already got. My poor people have got nothing.”  The revelation comes just weeks after Harry, , was pictured handing the jam roly-poly puddings that he raved about on I’m A Celebrity to rough sleepers. One tenant Joanne White, , said: “We’ve sent Harry letters, and not heard anything back. All we want to know ishe’s actually aware of what this is going to do to us.” Another, Edward Hyde, , added: “We just don’t want to be made shyhomeless. This isn’t a vendetta. It’s not about us against him. He’s got every right to do what he wants to do.” Wendy and husband Gerry have run the Belgravia as homes for vulnerable people with no deposits, references or guarantors since . Their tenants pay just pound a week including bills. Similar accommodation nearby costs more than double – and local homeless services are believed to be full. In , Pierfront Developments – with former West Ham and Spurs manager Redknapp and his we Sandra as directors – bought the property from the owner for pound.million.  The local council turned down plans to demolish the hotel – but it’s set to give the go-ahead on Tuesday to proposals to convert the inside of the building to  flats and build five mews houses on surrounding land. Sub-tenant Edward told us he moved in three and a half years ago after losing his job as a hospital porter. He said he did not qualy for support from Bournemouth Council because he was not a high priority candidate. Wendy and Gerry offered him a room after an outreach worker suggested the Belgravia. He said: “There’s nowhere in this town where you could move in without references, a deposit, and all of that. “You’ve got to be perfect to move in somewhere and be a key holder. You also need shythousands of pounds. “We don’t know how we’re going to raise enough money. We want to know support is going to be there. We want to be resettled. We don’t want to be on the streets.” Trevor Simpson, who moved in after leaving prison, said: “No-one really cares about homeless people. It’s the same across the whole country.  “Wendy will take anyone here. It doesn’t matter who you are, she’ll help youyou help yourself, and give you a roof over your head. “We’ve put objections to the council, but we can’t stop it. All we want is for the council to sit down with Harry, talk things through and let us know where we stand so we can find somewhere to go. “There is nowhere . Even the ASDA car park plays bagpipe music all night to keep people away. Nobody will take anyone without guarantors. Who’s going to guarantee us  “I couldn’t live on the street. It would physically kill me. I know eight people who died last year.” Tenants will be given a month’s notice to leave in writing at the start of April. They can be forgiven for feeling upset by pictures of Harry feeding homeless people at Bournemouth’s Sacred Heart church just a mile and a half away from the Belgravia on December . The star grinned as he said: “It’s all getting eaten.”   Trevor added: “Harry gave out jam roly-poly over Christmas and opened a charity shop the other week. But he’s not come here and spoken to us.” Fellow tenant Joanne said: “I don’t think he’s really taken on board how serious a problem it’s going to be.” Anton Oosthuizen, , who moved in after sleeping rough, said: “We don’t blame him. “We just want some help to find somewhere  to live. We don’t want to stop his venture. We wish him all the best. We’ve sent our letters to him recorded delivery. Why won’t he listen to us ” A design and access statement by a planning consultant hired by Pierfront states the Belgravia “has been converted to provide self-contained bedsit accommodation. The proposals would formalise the existing residential use and ensure a high standard of residential accommodation can be provided.” A letter sent by Pierfront Developments Limited to Wendy and Gerry Hunt in January says: “Please provide confirmation your clients will immediately provide possession on May , .”  Bournemouth Borough Council said: “We would urge all residents who think they are at risk of homelessness to make contact with the council’s Housing Options Team as soon as possible. “Our officers will help them look at rehousing options and make sure they maintain contact with the leaseholder of this property to help enable these timely discussions.” A source told us the application had been delegated to planning officers so, although it has yet to be formally agreed, it was highly unlikely it would be refused. A spokesman for Redknapp’s firm said: “I can confirm Pierfront Developments completed the purchase of the Belgravia Hotel in  with Mr Mrs Hunt being sitting tenants. “Pierfront Developments have a lease in place with Mr and Mrs Hunt, and from Pierfront Developments’ understanding the tenants sub-let the main hotel. “In August  Mr and Mrs Hunt signed a consent order, and notice was served in February to vacate the property by May . All legal proceedings were dealt with by both representatives’ solicitors.”

story: NewsLive like a Hobbit in this incredible home which could earn you £, a yearThe four-bed Hobbit house in Cornwall is grass-roofed and has a fireplace for marshmallow-roastingShareCommentsByClaire Gilbody-Dickerson:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThe Hobbit house youve always yearned for "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIf you ever fancied like like a Hobbit, well now you can and even earn pound, a year. An enchanting little Hobbit House in Cornwall, which is the spitting image of those seen in the three high fantasy adventure films, is now up for sale. Dreamy pictures of the house in St Mabyn, officially named as Toddalong Roundhouse, show a fun pathway leading up to the straw bale-built grass-roofed cottage. In the heart of the Cornish countryside, the house is positioned in the back garden of an open space four-bedroom house currently up for sale. Besides a kitchen and a bathroom, the house, which was branded by local newspapers as the quirkiest in the county, has all it takes for you to relax and enjoy the peace of the Cornish countryside.  Once you enter the house youll be amused by its peculiar traits, such as a miniature hobbit-sized door, weirdly-positioned bunk beds and a mezzanine on the other side, perfect for whoever has aspired at least once in their le to be either Frodo, Samwise, Pippin or Merry. It has a fire place both inside and outside so you can enjoy the typical rustic bonfire ritual of roasting sweet marshmallows. And while enjoying the outdoors you can let your imagination flow while looking over the panoramic views of Roughtor and Bodmin moor.  For the dreamers, the ceiling has a central opening to the sky, allowing for sunlight to shine through during the day and the starry night sky to accompany ones sleep.The imaginative property is currently available to rent for a minimum of two nights on AirBnB, but it is soon to be sold alongside the main four-bedroom one.It will be sold fully furnished and equipped as seen in the pictures.According to Rightmove , which is advertising the space, the grass-covered house could reap its buyer a pound, income each year. While there are bookings that need to be respected for the following  months, the letting availability will be entirely dependant on whoever is lucky enough to land a contract for the dreamy site once that term is up. The entire property is being sold at pound, and is listed for sale with Cole Rayment  White.
