story: NewsMan, , just  days from death after horror abuse from girlfriend speaks outAlex Skeel, , had boiling water poured over him, was physically attacked, denied food and kept isolated from loved onesShareCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsTwisted Jordan Worth banned Alex Skeel from their bed and kept food from him "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who was tortured and abused by his girlfriend for six years has spoken out about his horric ordeal in a new documentary. Alex Skeel had boiling water poured over him, was physically attacked, denied food and kept isolated from loved ones by partner Jordan Worth, who was later jailed. The -year-old was just  days from death when help finally reached him, reports the Sunday Express . Worth, , admitted grievous bodily harm and coercive controlling behaviour and was jailed for seven-and-a-half years at Luton Crown Court in April . Worth and Alex met at college in  when they were both  and the court was told from the abuse started early in the relationship.  My toddler son stopped eating and speaking because he watched his dad abuse me  A film about Alexs ordeal, Abused By My Girlfriend, narrated by Alex himself, is on BBC Three tomorrow. The case is said to be one of the most extreme cases of domestic violence witnessed by Bedfordshire Police. The film examines why Alex felt he couldnt escape and why he was reluctant to tell friends and family. His own family contribute to the film, including his twin brother, close friends and police. There is also footage of police interviews with Skeel and Worth. Worth is a picture of calmness as she is accused of cutting her boyfriend across the elbow, together with hitting him with a hammer. The kne wound was caused by Alex attempting to protect his head from her attack and required dozens of stitches.   In the film Alex catalogued countless days of injuries and coercive behaviour, some involving social media in which Worth would tell his family to stop communicating on Facebook . He was also told what to wear, periodically starved and hit with a beer bottle. The film begins with Alex explaining how he received his scars. He says: Thats where I got burned, my scars tell a story.   Thats stab wounds... they were caused by hammers hitting the skin. When police found me I was told I was  days away from death. I was in love in Jordan and it took me a long time to have the courage to say she was abusing me. People ask me why didnt you walk away, but its so complicated. Alex, who met Jordan when he was , said: I didnt care about girls until Jordan came along. She was very confident, caring and showed a real interest in me. But Worths mood darkened at Skeels th birthday party where she got jealous of a -year-old girl and targeted her with abuse, violently shouting at her.   My brutal boyfriend called a babysitter to look after our boy so I could dig my own grave A row saw the couple break up temporarily but she ed. They split again, this time for a year but, desperate to meet his son, TJ, Worth and Skeel moved in together. Alex said that in February : I woke up one morning to feel boiling water being poured on my back. It was horrible. It hurt, it was so sore. In the middle of the abuse another child a daughter Iris was born. When the police first called Worth said Alex had been self-harming. But PC ED Finn suspected abuse and ed to quiz Alex again. He said: Its good we got there when we did, because its so unusual with a female offender... it just didnt come together in our heads as quickly as it should have done. Alex was finally treated in AE and told his full story to police.Abused By My Girlfriend will be available on BBC Three tomorrow

title: new mum 24 given nine
story: NewsNew mum, , given nine months to live after morning sickness turned out to be cancerBrave Elizabeth Wagner, from Walton, Liverpool, welcomed her second son, Elijah, into the world just three months agoShareCommentsBySophie EvansEmilia Bona:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsElizabeth Wagner, pictured with her baby son Elijah, has been given just six to nine months left to live "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A -year-old new mum has been given just six to nine months left to live after being diagnosed with a rare and aggressive form of liver cancer . Brave Elizabeth Wagner was dealt the devastating blow just months after welcoming her second son, Elijah, into the world, the Liverpool Echo reports. Her family now fear that the terrible morning sickness that she suffered throughout her pregnancy was actually a symptom of the deadly disease.Her sister Hannah Wagner, , said: She was sick right through her pregnancy but thought it was morning sickness all the way through. We dont know nowthat was a symptom. Healthcare assistant Elizabeth, who also has a three-year-old boy, Ethan, with her partner Jairo, gave birth to little Elijah three months ago.   But days later, she was taken to hospital after developing excruciating pains in her sides. Doctors later told her she had  liver abscesses. And last week, she and her family were given the heartbreaking news that she actually had liver cancer, which was very rare and advanced. They have been told there is nothing medics can do.Now, Elizabeths loved ones are desperately appealing for help in funding a potentially le-saving proton beam therapy treatment that is not available on the NHS.If the treatment is identied as an option for the mum-of-two, she would need to travel to the USA for treatment - at a cost that her family cannot cover. Hannah told the Echo: She means so much to all of us.  None of us want to lose her. Shes the one whos crazy and funny and shes got two boys - she doesnt deserve to lose out on seeing them grow up. Elizabeth, from Walton, Liverpool, works at Fazakerley Hospital. Her family claim her cancer was initially missed by healthcare professionals. Hannah said: She started having pains in her side and it was after she had just given birth and she thought it was something to do with the pregnancy. That was pretty much straight [after having Elijah]. Elizabeth also suffered from sickness throughout her pregnancy. Her sister added: She didnt do anything about it after giving birth and then after a week or so her boyfriend took her to the AE because she was in that much pain.   It was during Elizabeths admission to hospital in December that doctors found  abscesses on her liver, which they opted to try and treat with a course of antibiotics. However, earlier this month, the new mother and her family say they were told that the abscesses were actually liver cancer - and doctors couldnt do anything. Elizabeth had only just moved into her new house with her young family. Devoted Jairo has now had to take on all the responsibilities of becoming a father again - while caring for his partner and making her healthy food. Hannah said: He has been amazing - hes looking after the kids, taking care of her, making her healthy food, he doesnt take his eyes off her. She added that the couple are planning to tie the knot in April.   Elizabeths family have set up a GoFundMe page in a bid to raise pound, to fund her travel and treatment in America. In a post on the page, Hannah writes: I am asking as many people as possible to please give us as much or as little as you can spare. This would enable us to be in a position to try and save my sisters le, we have no other options available to us. Elizabeth is a devoted partner to Jairo and an amazing mum to her two very young boys, she has so much to live for and is ready to fight this illness, we just need a bit of financial help.To visit the familys GoFundMe page or to donate, click here

story: NewsPrince George and Princess Charlotte may have exciting half term planned with Kate and WillsKate Middleton and Prince William dont appear to have any official engagements this week, and Prince George and Princess Charlotte are on half termShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  FEB NewsThe Cambridges love skiing "Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChildren up and down the country are looking forward to a week of fun next week as they get ready for half term. When Brooke Gibb went to Burrows Opticians In Normanton, West Yorkshire in May last year she was only expecting a brief, routine eye examination.However, when the optician found a swelling   Doctors at Royal Derby Hospital found a tumour on the back of Brookes brain during an MRI scan and decided to act immediately. She was transferred to Queen’s Medical Centre in Nottingham and underwent a major operation to remove the growth. The girl, who has eight brothers and sisters, spent a gruelling nine weeks in hospital only for doctors to announce that the tumour was cancerous and that she was unable to walk.Mckenzie Gibb, Brookes mum, told Derbyshire Live that the diagnosis was “awful”. story: NewsSperm donor who wants to father , children visits Australia to impregnate more womenThe man known only as Joe Donor claims to have impregnated over  women the world over - but has arrived in Australia having had no medical checksShareByFred Nathan:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThis American known only as Joe Donor claims to have fathered over  children the world over "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn American sperm donor is visiting Australia on his quest to impregnate women the world over. And he has admitted he wants to father , kids. Following the experience, Sharney and Liz began having second thoughts about Joe Donor and instead went to a fertility clinic. But on his Australian tour, he did manage to give another couple, Tracey and Bella, their eighth child - having already used another sperm donor for one of their previous seven.  In his interview, Joe Donor said he has delivered his semen to women in Queensland, southern Victoria, Adelaide and Sydney and believed he did not give anyone an STI by having sex with multiple women. title: i knew you were gone
story: NewsI knew you were gone. You were with me: Mums devastating letter to daughter year after she was killedLori Alhadeffs -year-old daughter Alyssa was one of  students killed in the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School shooting on Valentines Day in ShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news us-news video mums-heartbreaking-letter-daughter-anniversary-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLast Valentines Day -year-old AlyssaAlhadeff woke up, got dressed, and did her hair and make-up ready for school as ususual. Before she left her mum Lori handed her a gold gt bag containing a pair of earrings, chocolate bar and some hairbands. They both said I love you as Alyssa opened the car door and headed to Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Florida.Later that day a former student opened fire, killing  students and three teachers - including Alyssa.Lori never saw her little girl again.   A year after her death, Lori has penned a heartbreaking letter to her daughter. Mothers know. Intuition prevails, she writes. Mine came as soon as someone told me thered been a shooting at school. I knew you were gone. You were with me. I knew it. She talks about how her daughter wasnt looking forward to Valentines Day as she didnt have a Valentine.   She says it still feels like yesterday, writing: I wish I could take all the bullets for you. I just want you back. She writes about the final time she saw Alyssa, and updates her on all the things her two brothers have been getting up to.Since the horric shooting Lori has campaigned for change and set up the organisation Make Our Schools Safe.She made headlines around the world after she appeared on CNN the day after the shooting pleading with President Donald Trump to increase security in schools.Lori has published her full letter online, alongside a link to her school safety organisations fundraising page , with the title A Parkland moms Valentines Day letter to her daughter.  Loris letter in full Its Valentine’s Day. A day full of love, chocolates and flowers. For me, it is more than that now. Last Valentine’s Day was the last time I saw you. You wore a black and white dress. Your long dark hair dangled. Your makeup looked just right. Of course, your white Converse sneakers protected your feet as you walked in to Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School.Valentine’s Day is now about memories. Today, like all days, I remember. I remember you weren’t looking forward to going to school that day. Like many  year old girls, you wanted a Valentine and were disappointed that you didn’t have one. High school love is magic. I was  once and those butterflies had whirled inside of me too. I wanted that for you. I remember the golden gt bag I gave you that morning. It held a pair of diamond earrings to make you feel pretty, a chocolate bar to make you smile, and hair ties so you wouldn’t ask for mine.   I touched your ears, putting the stems of the earrings through your lobes. You said you were ready to go to school after that. You opened the car door. “I love you,” I said. “I love you, too,” you said.Valentine’s Day. The last time I saw you alive. ****A year has been a long time without you. So much has happened I want to tell you about. I watch your brothers miss you terribly. They want you to know they miss fighting with you. They say thank you for convincing dad to get unlimited WiFi. Dad fights for you every day. He’s your voice.   Grammy has honored you and became a school safety activist. We got a dog! Her name is Roxy and she’s a soccer player, like you. She kicks the ball around the yard, but sometimes puts it in her mouth. And your soccer team...wow, what a group. They wear your number eight on their sleeves and have started using it sideways to honor you. Infinity. Oh, and I found out about the time you jumped off a bridge down by the beach !Alyssa, you jumped off a bridge ! **** There are things I do in your memory that I never thought I could or would ever do.See, a mother’s protective instincts don’t leave when we lose the ones we love. I talk to other moms who have lost children. We talk about you. We talk about their kids. But when we look into each other’s eyes, we see it. A fire. I ran for the school board. I won! I screamed on national TV—words of rage directed at the President! I started a non-profit called Make Our Schools Safe and there is a law named after you in New Jersey--Alyssa’s Law.  **** Mothers know. Intuition prevails. Mine came as soon as someone told me there’d been a shooting at school. I knew you were gone. Rabbi Gutnick said, “Have faith, Lori.” I said, “No, you must start planning now.” You were with me. I knew it.We lost  students and three teachers.  beautul people we, as a community, needed to bury. You were the first. The next day, Rabbi Gutnick presided and hundreds of people came from all over the country. If you remember from Bat Mitzvah classes, shivas last seven days when a loved one dies. In those seven days, I got so many hugs from people who loved you. From family. From people I’d never met. So many that I injured my neck. People, in a sense, loved me until it hurt. ****It’s Valentine’s Day.As I remember you, grief washes over me. But that grief emboldens me to fight for change. I wish I could take all the bullets for you. It’s been a year since I saw you. You, in that black and white dress, those Converse on your feet, and that smile. I’ll never forget that smile. It feels like yesterday. I just want you back. Love forever, Mom

title: meet new el chapo
story: NewsMeet the new El Chapo – an evil billionaire ex-cop running worlds worst drug cartelEXCLUSIVE: Despite once being in the police, El Mencho is infamous for his sadistic crimes and has more power than everShareCommentsByChristopher Bucktin:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsA billionaire ex-cop dubbed El Mencho is now said to be filling the shoes of El Chapo "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJust when you get one notorious drugs lord banged up, along comes one El of a murderous shysuccessor ready to take his place. As Mexican cocaine king Joaquin “El Chapo” Guzman begins a le sentence, America’s Drugs Enforcement Administration must now hunt down an even more fearsome quarry. A cunning billionaire former avocado grower and cock-fighting enthusiast — who was once a COP. Nemesio Oseguera-Cervantes — aka El Mencho — is so fearless he even kidnapped the millionaire playboy sons of his now caged arch-rival. After setting up his own New Generation cartel in Jalisco state ten years ago, he made his mark in the bloodcurdling Narcos world by dumping  bound and tortured bodies in the streets of Mexican port Veracruz at rush hour.   Two years later, Mencho’s men raped, killed and set fire to a ten-year-old girl they mistakenly believed to be the daughter of one of their rivals. In , his assassins executed a man and his young son by detonating sticks of dynamite duct-taped to their bodies. Chapo’s partner Ismael “El Mayo” Zambada holds the title of the planet’s biggest drug dealer.But it is little wonder that Oseguera-Cervantes, , is the DEA’s most wanted, with a million bounty on his head.  His crystal meth, cocaine and heroin consignments not only flood the States, but they also hit the streets HERE and in Europe, Australasia, Africa and Asia too. “He’s public enemy number one,” said Paul Craine, who was head of the federal DEA in Mexico during the  arrest of Chapo. “And he’s got an army of thousands of bad guys.”   Chapo, , ran the feared Sinaloa state cartel and was immortalised in the Netflix series Narcos: Mexico. He was caught in  and finally sentenced last week. After his arrest, rival drug dealers shyfought a vicious battle with each other to fill the power vacuum. Chapo’s sons Ivan, , and Guzman,  — kidnapped at a restaurant by Mencho’s men in  and freed after Chapo coughed up an estimated million — were muscled out of the way for partner Mayo to take charge. But as a reclusive diabetic close to , his hold on the cartel is slipping. And while he is seen as a survivor of the old school drug runners who abide by mafia-like codes, former policeman Mencho is the image of the new Mexican cartel don.   His cartel embraces social media as a way to announce their presence – carrying out narco-terrorist attacks, beheadings and the dismembering of bodies, for the world to see. All the time Mencho stays in the shadows. He doesn’t make the kind of public challenges to shyauthority that have led to the downfall of other narcos including Colombia’s Pablo Escobar over the years. And he never, ever touches a phone. His foot soldiers keep order with assault rles and wear a unorm of black balaclavas and T-shirts shyemblazoned with the cartel logo. “He runs his cartel like a paramilitary,” says narcos expert Daniel Solis. “Its arsenal, and its organisation put the regular army to shame. “With the insight he gained while in the police, Mencho knows the power of a well-structured force. He has publicly stated he will die shyfighting rather than be taken alive. He expects the same of all his men.”  Mencho rose to infamy from humble beginnings. He dropped out of school at the age of ten to work on his family’s small avocado farm. Four years later he got a job guarding a weed crop before shysneaking into Calornia and setting up as a small-time dealer. He and his cousin were caught shytrafficking and he was deported in the early s. But on histo Mexico, he shymanaged to hide his criminal past and landed a job with the Jalisco state police. He left for the Millennium Cartel, an old ally of Chapo’s mob, then set up his own firm a decade ago which swtly became known for its horrying mass murders. “Its method of shykilling is more akin to ISIS than the shycartels,” adds Solis. “Never shybefore has how they kill, in the numbers that they kill, been seen in Mexico.” When Mencho is cornered he shydisplays his most barbaric streak.   On May , , the Mexican army planned to strike back at him with Operation Jalisco. In a pre-dawn raid, elite paratroopers and federal shypolice flown in by two military helicopters descended on a ranch where they believed Mencho was hiding. But the cartel was waiting in armoured trucks. One of the helicopters was hit, sending it crashing down in flames. Eight soldiers and a police officer were killed. Hours later, Mencho ordered his men to set fire to dozens of hijacked cars, buses, trucks, petrol stations and banks — gridlocking traffic and bringing Jalisco to its knees. The Mexican government was forced to send in , troops to secure the state. Now, in the wake of Chapo’s jailing, the DEA and Mexican authorities are strengthening their bid to bring Mencho down. If he were shycaptured tomorrow, US authorities would be expected to request his extradition, as they did with Chapo. But one DEA source doubts it will get that far. “Mencho’s such a killer, I’d be surprisedhe was captured alive,” he said.

title: dundee move was easy decision for aberdeens scott wright to make
story: Leaving a squad challenging at the top of the table for one struggling at the bottom may seem like a big decision for any young footballer to make.One that you might need a bit of time to think over.For Dundee’s on-loan winger Scott Wright, however, a phone call to Dens Park boss Jim McIntyre was all it took to convince him to head down from Aberdeen.And just two games into his temporary switch to dark blue, the Scotland U  international is already convinced his snap decision was the right one.“I’m loving it here and all the boys are making me feel really welcome. Now it’s a question of getting settled in as quick as I can and just playing football,” he said.“I had obviously spoken to Derek McInnes and he said to speak to Jim McIntyre before making any decision.“The gaffer at Aberdeen left it up to me.“He told me he’d love to have me still up there butI wanted to go and get games he understood.“So I spoke to the gaffer here on the phone and I loved everything he had to say. I jumped at the chance to come down here.”And the -year-old sees the draws against Hamilton and Kilmarnock since he arrived as proof this is a squad that can pull away from the relegation zone between now and the end of the season.“The only frustrating thing for me so far is that we’ve not taken six points out of six from the two games I’ve been involved in but I think all the fans and us as a team can feel from those performances that we are building momentum.“In the Hamilton game it was a case of everyone trying to get used to each other. A lot of us had only come in right before the deadline and we only really had one training session together.“It was about trying to get to know everyone’s games, their personalities. I think we are all starting to gel now and you can see that on the pitch.“Not having a game last weekend because we’re out of the cup has given us a bit more time to work on that. That gives us a better picture going into the game against Livingston this weekend.”Today’s trip to the Tony Macaroni Arena to face Livingston is a meeting with a team who have taken the Premiership by storm this term but have been struggling for a win of late.Since thumping Hearts - in mid-December, Gary Holt’s team have not won in eight outings. Wright does not see that as a sign this could be an easy  minutes for Dundee.“We have to treat it that every game from now on is going to be a big game for us and this will be.“We know how Livi will be and they will work hard but all we can do is just prepare the way we want to and work on how we can play. Hopefully, that will be enough.“They haven’t won in a few games but it’s a testimony to Livi how many points they have. They started the season so well.”Today, of course, will see Dundee asked to play on Livi’s much-criticised plastic pitch.The debate over their use has surfaced again this week via the PFA canvassing their members for views on them. While Wright is very much in the camp that prefers grass surfaces, the articial surface is not something he’s going to gripe about.“All we can do is get on with it and we are not going to use the pitch as an excuse,” he added.“Playing in Scotland, you get used to them.“However, I think having everyone playing on grass is something that would benefit the top league.“You prepare for a team each week but, for these games, you also have to prepare for the pitch as well.“All we can do as players is give our opinion about them.”

title: gomis set to take over as dundee united target hat trick of wins down at queen of the south
story: Veteran Morgaro Gomis is set to take over in midfield when Dundee United try to make it three wins on the bounce as they head for Queen of the South today.The -year-old is expected to replace Calum Butcher, who will serve the first game of a two-match ban after his red card in the Scottish Cup win at St Mirren last weekend.His second game on the sidelines will be the cup quarter-final against Ross County or Inverness Caley Thistle which has been confirmed for Sunday, March  at pm.The game is also being televised live on BBC Scotland.As well as continuing their recent winning run, the Tangerines will be looking for their third success of the campaign over Queens.To do that, though, manager Robbie Neilson is well aware they will have to keep in-form home striker Stephen Dobbie quiet.His spectacular strike in the cup at Aberdeen on Sunday was the -year-old’s th goal in just  appearances this term.“He has been on fire lately and someone we will have to get to grips with,” said Robbie.“He has a lot of quality, he knows how to score goals.“He’s just a very good player and I think he has the freedom of Dumfries these days. He’s a god down there.”United have their own in-form attacker in the shape of Pavol Safranko.The Slovakian, who’s on loan from Aalborg, has hit the net three times in his last four games.That’s taken his tally so far to  goals and he’s scored on the two previous occasions he’s faced the Doonhamers.“We been playing well and we’re looking for that to continue,” added Robbie.

title: legend maurice malpas reckons january business could help dundee united reach premiership
story: With a total of  appearances for Dundee United, there’s not many better qualied to speak on the state of things at Tannadice than Maurice Malpas.And the club legend reckons their January business has given them “a chance” of promotion back to the Premiership –they can keep displays up for more than  minutes.He said: “The last couple of games they’ve been good in the first half but ran out of steam in the second. If they can get the players bang at it for more of the game I think you have to say they have a chance.“There is a bigger iety of player to choose from now and they have some players who are willing to put a boot in, which you need when games aren’t going your way.“They have a chance of getting up but they can’t drop many points.”As for his own situation, Malpas is quite content looking on from the stands after being assistant to Richie Foran at Inverness last season.Malpas added: “These days I watch United on a Saturday and do a bit of babysitting.“I’ve no desperation to get back in. If something came along I’d consider it but when you’ve been in the game as long as I have you can’t see the wood for the trees. Once you’re out you see the things that really matter in le and I’m quite happy.“I do a bit of coaching over in America a few times a year which gives me my wee fix but I’m quite happy where I am.”

title: livingston may be off form but dundee boss jim mcintyre expects a tough test today
story: Dundee boss Jim McIntyre is taking nothing for granted when his improving team face off-form Livingston at the Tony Macaroni Arena today.The Dark Blues head over the Forth on the back of displays against Hamilton and Kilmarnock that, but for injury time mishaps, would have earned six points instead of two.An injury-time equaliser cost victory at Accies while the chance to take maximum points against Killie last week slipped away when Kenny Miller’s penalty was saved in the fth minute of time added on.Now it’s on to Livi, who’ve not won since before the winter break but Jim believes Gary Holt’s team remain formidable opponents.“It’s natural that at some stage of a season you will have a dip and they’ve still had a brilliant season. They have some very good players,” he said.“The first thing we have to do is try to win our battles but don’t forget they have scored some quality goals, some good team goals.“We have to try to make sure inidually we get the better of them and try to go and create opportunities to win the game.”Dundee go into the clash with controversy over plastic pitches like Livi’s rekindled by a PFA survey showing top-flight players are unied in opposition to them.The manager is also in that camp but hasn’t forgotten that defeat at the Tony Macaroni in his first game in charge was down to what happened in the air and not the surface.That day back in October his team conceded four goals from set pieces.“We didn’t deal with set plays and that killed us. It was an eye-opener that day in terms of what we had to work with,” he said.“There’s no doubt, though, the surface is an advantage. I was the manager of a team, Queen of the South, who had an articial surface andyou train on it every day it’s a definite help.“At the same time I’m not trying to detract from how well Livingston have done because they’ve done exceptionally well.”Dundee are still nursing a few niggling injuries from that Killie draw, but it’s hoped everyone who was on duty then will be available. Midfielder Ethan Robson is expected to recover in time from the groin injury that forced him to miss that game.

title: party goers turning dundee street into bottle graveyard
story: Locals fear streets around one of Dundee’s busiest nightle spots are turning into a “bottle graveyard”.Areas around South Ward Road have been left in a mess in recent months, with revellers knocking back booze on the streets and using electrical boxes as tables before moving on to city nightspots.Pictures taken earlier this week show beer cans and bottles of spirits dumped opposite the petrol station.One local said the area was particularly bad yesterday morning after party-goers had been out on the town.He said: “I came down Thursday morning just before am.“I was greeted with sick, urine, bottles of spirits and empty cans of beer.“It always seems to be worse on a Thursday morning after a Wednesday evening.“It’s a bottle graveyard on the way into work.“I would assume most of the revellers are partaking in student nights out and are trying to save themselves a few quid.“I feel sorry for the street sweepers who need to clean these areas up because it’s a total disgrace.“This isn’t a one-off either as it’s happening every week.“I came down today and it was totally clear, which leads me to believe it’s a problem related to Wednesday nights.”Despite the worries of residents, owners of nightclubs in the area have denied any knowledge of their customers drinking in the streets before entering their premises.The owner of Carbon and Kush nightclub on South Ward Road, Tahir Ramzan, said he was unaware of issues of alcohol being consumed on the surrounding streets.He said: “This is the first I’ve heard about this.“Anything that happens en route to the club is outwith our control.“The problem isn’t directly outside the clubs and might be impacting more on the petrol garage.“We certainly don’t have issues with our customers who come in during the week. They come and enjoy themselves.“Given it is not happening directly outside the club it’s outwith our control.”A spokesman for Club Tropicana and Aura next door urged customers and residents to get in touchthere were any further issues.He said: “We haven’t received any complaints regarding this matter. However, we will investigate with the information you have provided us with.“If anyone would like to get in touch with us simply email info@auradundee.”Dundee City Council had not responded to a request for comment at the time of going to press.

title: young women urged to attend voting event run by dundee womens festival
story: Organisers of a centenary suffrage conference have urged young women to turn out in their droves.Dundee Women’s Festival will run the event on Saturday March  entitled “Why Should I Bother to Vote ” and is stressing that it is aimed at the - age group.Chairwoman Prue Watson, , said: “We want younger people to come along instead of people my age.“They are the future and we also want to encourage them to vote because people have died in the past fighting for this right.“I would tell young women that it is important to vote, you can change things by voting.“We are hoping to have  young people at the event but so far we have only got  registered so there is a real push on to encourage more.“The Scottish Parliament centenary grant has allowed us to host a conference on the fight for women’s suffrage and what our vote means today.“Sofriends, daughters or granddaughters are aged between  and , then sign up and find out.“We will encourage them by looking at the history of women’s suffrage and our political system“There are a lot of very interesting speakers lined up including the author Ajay Close, who is a great writer.“I am sure the women who turn up will be very interested in her talk about suffragettes and what they did in Scotland.“Many suffered terrible forced feeding in Perth prison.”Ms Watson added: “We were awarded £, by the Scottish Parliament to stage the event and it allows us to accommodate  people at the conference which is being held at Dundee and Angus College’s Gardyne Campus.“The event is free and lunch is provided, plus there are workshops in the afternoon.“I am sure it will be a popular day.”The event starts at .am.

title: Autistic boy leads the way in inpsiring kindness project
story: GABRIEL Erasmusrsquos parents have always believed his superpower was his love for people.The -year-old ndash who is autistic, has dyslexia and learning dficulties ndash was unable to speak until he was five.But he was so fascinated with faces he would smile when touching them.And his proud mum Victoria says he has developed an uncanny ability to feel and absorb the emotional discomfort of others.This desire to help gets his creative impulses flowing.His latest venture, inspired by his sadness for an orphan boy he has come to know in his father Jonrsquos South African homeland, has started a kindness craze.His idea to reach out to this boy with a card to cheer him up has inspired hundreds of pupils to join in.Mrs Erasmus, a hotelier whose portfolio includes the Invernessrsquos Glen Mhor Hotel, said for years the family has been helping orphaned children in South Africarsquos Kwa Zulu region.Four years ago they founded the South African Childrenrsquos Charitable Trust and have visited the area with their four children.Mrs Erasmus said: ldquoGabriel came home from school upset one day. His head teacher had been talking about how to build up resilience.ldquoGabriel told him when he has a bad day, I make him feel better, but his -year-old friend at Ikhethelo lsquodoesnrsquot have a mummy to make him feel betterrsquo.Gabriel started to ldquopanic asking how orphaned children could learn resilience or even know they were loved.Mrs Erasmus said: ldquoBefore I could answer, he was asking for a paper and pen to write a card to tell the boy he was special, that he could get through anything and that Gabriel loved him.ldquoThe irony here is that Gabriel cannot write or read and yet he was doing the only thing he could think of to help. He was prepared to work out how to make  cards for the  children at Ikhethelo.Working with printers the youngster created three cards for his pals at the childrenrsquos villages.And the scheme has grown from there.The family split their time between Inverness and Edinburgh, where Gabriel goes to school and gets one-to-one support for his complex needs.Pupils in two Edinburgh schools, as well as those at Cannich Bridge Primary, are now sending cards to the South African youngsters ndash and receiving replies.Posting costs are met by the Erasmusrsquos charity.Amanda Graham, head teacher at Cannich Bridge Primary, said: ldquoIt makes the children in-volved think about others which is really important.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: Council agrees budget for 2019 20
story: It says thebudget is set to deliver pound. million savings over the next three years with a "Change Fund" of pound. million set aside to help "resource and deliver the change programme".Investment of an additional and recurring pound. million for roads maintenance was also approved, with plans for how this will be spentto be brought to a future meeting of the councils development and infrastructure committee.Members also agreed to raise Council Tax by three per cent.Budget leader, Councillor Alister Mackinnon, said: ldquoOur workforce is vitally important to communities. Not just in the services they provide, but, as one of the biggest employers in Highland, council jobs are fundamental to the sustainability of many communities. So a budget for jobs is really good news for people.ldquoA key element of the feedback we received is that we have many cumbersome, complicated and bureaucratic processes. We need to do things dferently, streamlining processes, be more outward looking and adopt best practice.ldquoAn overwhelming message is that we need to be more efficient. Basically, we need to get a grip on our expenditure. As a result we have been examining every budget line and turning over every stone, to make sure that we are getting the best results from the resources being used and challenging where performance can be improved.ldquoIf you always do the same things in the same way, you will get the same results. It is time to change how we do things and so this is a budget for change."The change fund is an exciting element of our budget strategy and will underpin our programme of change over the coming year.Council leader Margaret Davidson said: ldquoThis is a decent, thoughtful and ambitious budget which will help move us into the future, protecting jobs and services."It aims to set the council on a journey of much needed change. We are all ambitious for improvement and what has struck me is the huge buy-in from all staff in challenging circumstances.ldquoThis budget will enable us to be sustainable and I am really confident that we have the necessary knowledge and expertise in our top team to take forward the change programme that is required.Chief executive Donna Manson added: ldquoThis budget process has been about us being connected. Connected to our communities, to our staff, to our partners, to each other ndash building relationships and enabling better conversations and improved understanding.ldquoI really appreciate the input from staff across the organisation during the whole engagement process, and for some really honest feedback. I am equally delighted with the really positive engagement across the political groups.ldquoWe need to manage all our resources, to redesign, to become more resilient, to be more efficient, to invest in our workforce and to plan for the future. We need to embed effective performance management and effective scrutiny.ldquoThe Corporate Plan will be coming to council in March and this will focus on scrutiny and driving performance. It will underpin the work of the council moving forward, ensuring that we use all our resources to the best effect ndash and the engagement with communities and staff will be a continuing process throughout the year. I look forward to getting back out to see staff from next week onwards.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: Cycle ride aims to help Highlands special needs charity
story: SUPPORTERS of a leline service for children and young adults with special needs are to take part in a sponsored cycle ride to raise desperately-needed funds.The Special Needs Action Projectis facing an uncertain future after Highland Council turned down the charityrsquos annual grant of pound, ndash  per cent of the total running costs of pound,.After hearing the charity might have to close, two members of Snaprsquos youth club decided to do something to help.Dean Stewart and Bradley Morrall, both aged , suggested a fundraiser and as a result, a sponsored cycle ride will be held on Saturday March  at the Highland Cycle Ability Centre at Cantraybridge.They and others aim to cycle  km by completing laps of the track.Deanrsquos mother Carol Macdonald said her son had attended Snap for many years.ldquoIt has enabled and encouraged him and many others to enjoy le, have fun, learn, grow and flourish with many dferent challenges, she said.ldquoSnap is a much-needed leline for children and young adults, families, siblings and carers.ldquoSnap is like a great big hug. It provides warmth, security, comfort, friendship and caring when needed.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: Cyclists gather pollution data in Inverness
story: CLEAN air campaigners have strapped pollution sensors onto their bikes to expose the cityrsquos toxic air hotspots.The Highland Cycle Campaign is working with a student-led research project from Cambridge University to monitor air quality near roadways because of fears official figures are not capturing ldquodangerous levels of pollution.So far six members have used the pound monitors in ious areas including the A trunk road.And there are plans to extend its reach to the rest of the Highlands.Secretary Anne Thomas, who acts as local co-ordinator for Friends of the Earth Scotland, said the devices are showing where the most polluted areas are.She said: ldquoThe first maps show pollution levels on Academy Street and at the Longman roundabout as particularly high.And she claimed that the levels did seem, in some cases, to be breaching standards ldquowhich should have been met in .She added: ldquoIn reality there is no safe level of pollution which is responsible for thousands of premature deaths a year across Scotland.Mrs Thomas hopes the findings inspire more people to cycle as studies show car drivers spend longer in toxic air than walkers or cyclists on main roads.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: Date finally set for demolition of eyesore Eastgate Hostel in Inverness
story: WORK is finally set to start on tackling the fire-ravaged Eastgate Hostel in Inverness ndash almost SIX years after the blaze.A start date of March  has been set to begin the demolition of the High Street building which has been shrouded in scaffolding to the frustration of nearby businesses and community leaders for years.The announcement follows a long-running campaign by the Inverness Courier which has kept up the pressure in calling for action and ensuring the issue has remained in the headlines ndash and not forgotten.A spokesman for the owners said following successful negotiations with a demolition contractor the work would begin to take down the frontage of the building and remove the fire-damaged interiors.It is expected to take up to  weeks.Work would start five years and  months after the blaze in April .Community and business leaders have welcomed the news.Crown and City Centre Community Council chairwoman Pat Hayden welcomed the announcement but wondered why work had not started in mid January as previously expected.ldquoI am sorry to say I will only believe it when the workmen are on site, ldquo said Mrs Hayden who congratulated the Inverness Courier for keeping up the pressure since the building was damaged in April .Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael said: ldquoThis is a key city centre location which has for too long been blighted by scaffolding .ldquoThe reinstatement of the High Street is a signicant improvement and I welcome the commitment made by the owners to invest in this key site,she said.Central ward councillor Bet McAllister said it would especially help businesses in the High Street.ldquoI am also heartened to hear of the ongoing commitment to ensure that a replacement building is constructed at the earliest opportunity, she said.But chiropodist Jim Crawford whose business is nearby remained unconvinced. ldquoThere have been so many  dawns, he said. ldquoIf it doesnrsquot start by March , the council should take it over.A spokesman for the buildingrsquos owners said specialist contractors will initially remove asbestos from the site before the scaffolding is removed.The plan is that each stone for the front will be marked and set aside for reuse in the rebuild which has now been approved.The spokesman said the current contract is for the demolition to facilitate the removal of the scaffolding, but the intention was to rebuild fairly soon afterwards.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: Inverness firm says Brexit is making customers cautious
story: UNCERTAINTY over the UKrsquos withdrawal from the European Union is causing people to delay home improvements according to an Inverness company.Cairngorm Windows has enjoyed its best start to a year in  years but managing director David Dowling says domestic customers are holding off finalising orders.ldquoPeople carrying out house improvements are approaching us but Brexit is delaying them from pressing the button he said.ldquoIn addition, our German fitted kitchen supplier have notied us of a . per cent import duty tax on all deliveries after March  in the absence of a deal going through.ldquoHowever, wersquove a record-breaking forward workbook thanks to the strong volume of orders from housebuilders while council contracts are at their highest level in  years.A pound, new computer operated cutting machine was fitted in January to drive forward Cairngormrsquos high-tech production process which saw a record , windows manufactured last year.The company aims to produce , windows this year and break the , barrier next year.Mr Dowling said housebuilders like Tulloch Homes, Springfield Homes, Compass and Scotframe had signicantly stepped up their forward orders while windows were being sold as far away as Swindon.Wersquove a strong domestic business where we supply and fit from fitted windows to fitted kitchens, he said.ldquoBut customers are currently telling us theyrsquore holding off the spend because of Brexit causing uncertainty to household budgets.ldquoWe hope that situation clears before too long.The company, which employs  people, installed a pound, automatic welder and corner cutter last year.It has been in business for  years.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: Inverness mentoring project aims to improve lives
story: AN INVERNESS mentoring programme is among the projects set to benefit from a pound million windfall for communities across the Highlands.Communities Secretary Aileen Campbell visited Charleston Academy as she announced the funding under the Scottish Governmentrsquos Aspiring Communities Fund.She met staff and pupils involved with a programme which sees young people mentor younger children at Kinmylies Primary School and Nursery.Charleston is one of nine Highland schools taking part in the Growinggether in the Community scheme run by Forres-based Ecologia Youth Trust which has been awarded pound,.During her visit, Ms Campbell heard from pupils how the scheme is helping to increase their wellbeing and confidence as well as strengthening community links.Jake Weston , who is among those who have taken part, mentored a young boy who was initially isolated from other children.ldquoHe was able to make friends and share lunch at the table with other children which he had not done previously, he said.ldquoI have gained a lot of confidence.Logan Parkersaid she had also grown in confidence.ldquoI would recommend it definitely ndash  per cent, she said.Ms Campbell said local communities understood what worked in their own areas and the funding would enable them to help create a more equal Scotland.ldquoIt will support organisations across the Highlands and Islands to deliver tangible, innovative approaches to improve lives based on local priorities and will address poverty and inequality in their area, she said.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: Inverness pupils show winning ways in business competition
story: YOUNG business brains from across the Highlands were put to the test in a competition which sharpened their entrepreneurial skills and raised money for a deserving cause.Teams of six from local schools competed in the event organised by Highland Hospice.Secondary school pupils took each other on for the Young Highland Apprentice title, while primary children battled it out in their own junior event.The aim in both cases was to come up with a new product or service that could be sold to raise funds for the hospice.Pupils from Lochardil Primary School in Inverness triumphed in the junior category for their Rocks and Crosses game, a version of noughts and crosses using hand-painted rocks which comes with a gt bag that doubles up as the game board.Sales raised a total of pound. and saw the school crowned winners after a presentation at Inverness College UHI this week.Judges said they were impressed with their business acumen as well as their knowledge of the hospice and the work it does.Winning pound for their school courtesy of event sponsors Tailormade Moves, teacher Muriel Murray said: ldquoTheyrsquore delighted, really proud of themselves.ldquoItrsquos good to see their hard work recognised.In the older age category it was a team from Fortrose Academy who were triumphant, and Tain Royal Academy were runners-up.A team of fth years ran a whole iety of fundraising events between September and January that allowed them to present the hospice with a cheque for pound..Speaking about the impact of the competition as a whole, hospice community fundraiser Katie Gibb said: ldquoAs Highland Hospice is a vital service for the whole of the Highland community, this is a great way for us to raise awareness about our services within the younger generation.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: aberdeen held 2 2 by premierships bottom side st mirren
story: ABERDEEN suffered a damaging - draw with the Premiership#s bottom side St Mirren at Pittodrie in a match also marred by an injury to defender Tommie Hoban.Dropping points at home to the team rock bottom of the table will be hammer blow to their chances of overtaking second placed Rangers in the Premiership.The only positive, albeit minor, is that the Dons did not lose ground on Rangers who were held - by St Johnstone.A dismal day for the Reds was made even worse when on loan Watford defender Hoban was stretchered off with a knee injury late in the first half.Aberdeen fell behind to a penalty from Duckens Nazon before Lewis Ferguson headed an equalizer in the first half.However Buddies went ahead again through a strike from Kyle McAllister before a goal from prolic scorer Sam Cosgrove restored parity.Aberdeen made two changes to the side that defeated Championship Queen of the South - in the Scottish Cup fth round on Sunday.One was enforced with right-back Shaleum Logan ruled out with an ankle injury sustained in that cup victory.He was replaced by Mikey Devlin who made his first Aberdeen starts since a - defeat of Hibs on November .Devlin had been ruled out for three months with a foot tendon injury.Following his impressive sht as a half-time substitute in the cup tie Niall McGinn was handed a start with Stevie May dropping to the bench.Aberdeen should have netted the opener in the th minute when McGinn#s corner kick from the left found Lewis Ferguson racing in at the back post but he headed wide from eight yards out.Moments later McGinn raced onto a clever through ball from Mackay-Steven.Racing towards the by-line McGinn drilled a low, inviting cross along the face of goal but there were no takers.However it was relegation battling St Mirren who went ahead in the th minute when goal machine Sam Cosgrove, on  goals in the last  games, tugged down Paul McGinn.Referee Craig Thomson awarded a penalty that was converted by Duckens NAZON who fired the spot kick in off keeper Joe Lewis# right hand post.Aberdeen threatened in the th minute when Cosgrove played a superb through ball that split the defence to release Greg Stewart.Keeper Vaclav Hladky raced off his line to win the ball in a - but Stewart was left poleaxed inside the box as play raged on.Eventually Buddies kicked the ball out to allow Stewart to receive treatment.Aberdeen equalized in the nd minute when a corner from Mackay-Steven was flicked on by Mikey Devlin to the back post.Teenager FERGUSON had drted in unchecked and clinically headed home from eight yards.The Reds should have gone ahead moments later when Stewart squared a pass to McGinn but with the goal beckoning he scooped a shot over from  yards.Aberdeen suffered an injury set-back in the rd minute when on loan Watford defender Tommie Hoban was stretchered off with a knee injury.The defender went down when his studs looked to have caught in the surface going for the ball in front of the Main Stand.There was no contact with a St Mirren player as he appeared to twist awkwardly.Clearly in distress Hoban received treatment on the pitch before being stretchered off.It was the latest injury blow for the Watford defender who has only recently ed from five months out following shoulder surgery in August.Hoban also missed the whole of the previous season having suffered  a knee cruciate ligament injury that required surgery.St Mirren should have gone ahead soon after the break when Kyle McAllister#s cross from the right found Brad Lyons unmarked  yards out but his header flashed title: aberdeen cruise ship worker given advice on achieving dream by oprah winfrey
story: An Aberdeen-born cruise ship worker was stunned when he was offered career advice by one of the biggest names in showbiz.Grant Martin, of the city centre, who has worked with entertainment teams on ships around the world for the last seven years, brought his seafaring career to a perfect end by working on a cruise hosted by his lelong hero, Oprah Winfrey.As part of his role with Holland America Line, the -year-old worked as assistant cruise director on Oprah’s Girls’ Getaway Cruise on board Nieuw Statendam.The budding TV presenter admitted he was star-struck – even more so when he was asked to be the US talk show host’s personal chaperone.Grant, who grew up in Garthdee, said: “I originally only started working on cruises because I wanted to take a gap year. Seven years later I am still here! I had been a massive fan of Oprah since I was very young so it was amazing to be part of her cruise.“I was doing a few dferent tasks on board and then I was asked to escort Oprah around the ship.“It was just incredible. My le paused for a moment because I just couldn’t believe what I was doing.“Even later on I didn’t think she would recognise me because there were about , people on the ship but she did.“She even took the time to give me a few pointers when I said I was hoping to be a presenter.“To finish my cruise ship career on the ultimate high is just the greatest feeling.”Grant has visited  countries in the past seven years but is now planning tohome to the north-east next month to pursue his career in TV.“Hopefully one day I can become a host myself,” he added.“I’ve already done work placements with STV and my own YouTube channel is growing as well which is really exciting.“I’m really looking forward to pursuing my dream job.”

title: dancing brings light and beauty amid the grief to ardfern
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe Nowby Laura MaxwellWithin This Dust is an interpretive dance performance inspired by the most horrying incident of our time: the   terror attacks.A packed Craignish Village Hall held host to the Dundee-based Shaper Caper performance on Wednesday February .Inspired by photographs of the   fallout, choreographer Thomas Small has created a performance that has been seen to bring tears due to its beauty and the tragedy of this story. First performed in , Within This Dust has gone on to be staged all over the UK and internationally, including at the   memorial and museum.Especially inspired by Richard Drew#s unforgettable photograph, The Falling Man, Within This Dust details the experience of witness, Lisa Hood, and victim, Vince Virr, of the   attacks.The witness finds herself surrounded in dust, made of crumpled paper, and begins a grieving process of hunting through the papers, finding meaning in the words, as someone tries to tidy around her. The second act features the victim joining the witness, creating a connection that will inevitably be broken, when finally, in the third act, the victim is alone, caught between a choice of the smoke and fire within the collapsing building or the  metre drop to freedom.It was a very poignant performance, tenderly expressing the horror of the incident, perhaps now weakened due to overindulgence. When the lights came up everyone stayed where they were, perhaps a little too stunned to move. Chatter was in whispers, for respect to people who could not hear them.As the narrator of the show captured and pieced together from coverage of the attacks said, the dust has not settled, and never will. The losses of the people in the planes and buildings is still felt, and the wider western world is still wary, still learning, still recovering.Within This Dust manages to depict the horror of that day beautully, and more importantly, delicately. No easy task for a grieving world.PIC:Craignish Village Hall was full. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood amongst the #dust#. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Lisa Hood. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood collecting dust. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood and Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustVince Virr facing the smoke, or the window. _aWithinThisDust

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: rest and be thankful mitigation project moves to next phase
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe next phase of the works to form landslide mitigation catch-pits next to the A at the Rest and Be Thankful is now underway.The £.M project started in spring  with works now continuing with the construction of the fourth catch-pit next to the road side.  These landslide mitigation measures involve the excavation of debris flow catch-pits next to the A.The catch-pits are designed to stop debris reaching the road from a landslide down the channels above each catch-pit location, helping to keep the A open.  Once completed, this fourth catch-pit will provide an additional , tonnes of debris storage capacity, bringing the total volume protection of the catch-pits to approximately , tonnes.In addition to the catch-pits, works on the additional protection measures at Glen Kinglas, approximately three miles from the Rest and Be Thankful, will continue.  The works at Glen Kinglas involve the re-use of the excavated rock from the Rest and be Thankful to form landslip mitigation bunds above streams along Glen Kinglas. The bunds will help reduce the risk of debris reaching the A in the event of a landslide.This project allows BEAR Scotland to maximise the benefit of recycling the material being excavated from the Rest and Be Thankful while minimising the overall cost of these works.To keep roadworkers and motorists safe throughout the works, temporary traffic lights will be in place on the A at each location. This next phase of the works is expected to last approximately  weeks.Commenting on the works, Eddie Ross, BEAR Scotland’s North West Representative said: #The installation of the next stages of the mitigation measures will provide more protection and resilience against any future landslips blocking this key route at both the Rest and Be Thankful and Glen Kinglas.#The temporary traffic lights are necessary to keep our teams as well as users of the route safe during the works, and the teams will do all they can to complete the project as quickly and safely as possible.#We encourage road users to plan their journeys in advance by checking the Traffic Scotland website for up to date travel information.#

title: human rights monitor philppa bonella speaks at ms centre
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowSt Margaret’s Justice and Peace Group invited Philppa Bonella to Lochgilphead on Tuesday February  to talk about her experiences as a human rights monitor on the Ecumenical Accompaniment Programme in Palestine and Israel .She was in the Holy Land for three months last year and spent time on the West Bank in Palestinian villages surrounded by Israeli settlements.Philippa told her audience that the EAPPI sends batches of people of all nationalities to the Holy Land for these three-month stints, where the monitors are split into small groups and must operate in pairs for safety.She recalled particular incidents – schools tear-gassed by Israeli troops, homes searched in raids during the middle of the night, families prevented from picking their olives, Palestinian villages surrounded by Israelis in mobile homes, supported by Israeli government-funded water and electricity supplies.Human rights monitors must be impartial and Philippa did her utmost to present a balanced picture and all EAPPI monitors share their findings and experiences with the UN with the intention of furthering solutions in this troubled region. Her conclusions drawn from experience was that when the monitors were around, there may have been unpleasant situations, but no tragedies. When there was no monitor around – clearly defined by their unorms – people died.Philippa had only been home for eight weeks when she spoke to the Justice and Peace Group, and she admitted that she was still processing the often brutal and violent scenes she had witnessed. And though she wryly joked that it had not exactly been a picnic, she encouraged her audience to become involved in the work of EAPPI – through prayer, support, even by volunteering to be a monitor .For more information, visit eappi.org en or visit the EAPPI Facebook page @EAPPI.WCCPIC:Her stories of the hardships in Israel kept visitors engaged. no_aholylandPhillipa Bonella speaking at the MS Centre. no_aholyland

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: ayr united 2 inverness 3
story: NewsAyr United  Inverness : John Roberston hails Somerset Park among best grounds in worldThe Inverness gaffer was full of praise for the old fashioned surroundings as his side clung on in the face of a stirring fightback.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsNathan Austin puts Caley - up "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJohn Robertson hailed Somerset Park as one of the best grounds in the WORLD after Caley held off a storming Ayr fightback. Inverness were three up and on easy street after a crazy opening  minutes which saw United gt-wrap the game. But a Lawrence Shankland inspired comeback almost grabbed a share of the spoils for Ian McCalls title contenders. A relieved Robertson said: Had it finished - you wouldnt have been surprised. Somerset Park is one of these grounds that sucks you inyou give them a snf. Its a good throwback and their fans make it intimidating and a good atmosphere for teams when you lose a goal. Its brilliant...one of the best grounds in the world to come and play your football. In the past we might have lost a game like this so Im delighted.  Ayr knew a win here would take them top of the Championship and started well with Robbie Crawford missing a good chance in the first minute. But they soon hit the self destruct button as their defence went AWOL to allow Nathan Austin in for a double before Liam Polworth rammed home a third. The game looked over with barely  minutes on the clock and shellshocked Ayr took time to regroup. Coventry-bound Michael Rose rocked the post with a header before Michael Moffat drew a fingertip save from Cammy Mackay. McCall turned to the bench at half time and introduced top gun Shankland who immediately turned the tide. He set up Declan McDaid to haul Ayr back into the contest with a close range finish eight minutes after the restart. And a resurgent Ayr thought they had a penalty when Carl Tremarco appeared to handle in the box but ref Nick Walsh waved away loud protests. United continued to pour forward as the clock ticked down and Shankland set up a grandstand finish when slamming home a  yard free kick with five minutes left.  But their comeback proved too little too late as Inverness clung on. Ayr boss McCall said: Im just gutted. Weve conceded three goals and at least two of them were gted with just crazy defending. And were the team with the best defensive record in the league. I think a draw would’ve been fair but it’s just one of those nights.
